PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Due to a production error, a portion of the proceedings of the Senate on Wednesday, 1 April has been omitted from the printed Daily Hansard circulated this morning. Proceedings from approximately 12.04 p.m. to 2.45 p.m. are affected. The Senate Daily Hansard is being reprinted urgently and a corrected copy will be available this afternoon. As an interim measure, Hansard is distributing to each senator's office a photocopy of Question Time from yesterday. As well, the parliamentary database will have the corrected version loaded and available by midday today.
—Mr President, can you explain why the `red'—the business sheet—is not available?
—It is being circulated now.
—In the spirit of National Wool Day, and wearing my red Holeproof Heroes Australian wool socks, I want to ask a question of the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate.
—Are you wearing the red socks?

—They are very good socks, Australian made. With the reduction of the stockpile, why will the Government not now reduce the wool tax in order to give wool growers the opportunity to reinvest and further build their vitally important industry?
—I think the Government's position on the stockpile and the method of its disposal has been exhaustively debated and explained. I have nothing to add to what is on the record in that respect.

—I ask the Minister for Shipping and Aviation whether he is aware of reports that the Civil Aviation Authority plans to reduce charges to the aviation industry in the coming financial year. Can he confirm whether those reports are accurate?

—I am very pleased to advise the Senate that an extremely tangible benefit of the Government's restructuring of aviation regulation in Australia is about to be delivered to the industry that it serves. Honourable senators would know that the Civil Aviation Authority, under its extremely competent board and senior management, has been implementing the policy of the Government in undergoing a very major restructuring of the organisation which, over a period of five years, will lead to a reduction of almost half its staff.

PARA.TAB: Although that restructuring is fundamentally only in its first completed year, the Civil Aviation Authority is about to advise the aviation industry that it will cut airways charges to the industry in real terms by $96m in the coming financial year and a further $66.5m in real terms in the financial year 1993-94. The charges cover en route air traffic control services, terminal navigation and rescue and fire facilities.

The savings flow from a major restructuring of the organisation of the Authority, including a reduction in staff of over 2,000 over the period January 1991 to 30 June 1992 and the more efficient delivery of services. These significant cuts in staffing levels have been achieved, to the great credit of both management and unions, without any industrial disputation.

The CAA has also adopted the approach of buying systems which are already available and has avoided, where possible, the higher risk and often expensive approach of developing its own systems. The TAATS project is the most recent example of this new approach, I am pleased to say. The dramatic efficiency gains achieved by the CAA in a very short time are to be commended. This further advances the efficiency gains already enjoyed by the aviation industry and the travelling public as a result of the Government's micro-economic reform program.

The major airlines have cut their own staff by around 30 per cent in the past 12 months and are also carrying 30 per cent more passengers than they were prior to that time. This has flowed through to consumers, with average air fare costs falling significantly since October 1990. The CAA's reduced charges will assist the airlines to operate even more efficiently and maintain these competitive air fares.

I conclude by saying that a $96m cut in charges in what effectively is the first year of the full impact of the restructuring is to the great credit of the board, the management and the workers of the Civil Aviation Authority.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to Senator Evans representing the Treasurer. I refer the Minister to the views of his colleague the former Minister for Finance, Senator Peter Walsh, in the latest issue of Australian Labor Left that:

PARA.TAB: In 1989 we should have cancelled the tax cuts scheduled for 1 July, which had, of course, been locked in by the agreement with the ACTU 12 months earlier. And then we wouldn't have had to put nearly so much weight on monetary policy. Interest rates wouldn't have hit 20 per cent and we wouldn't have had a recession of the magnitude that we now have.

QUESTION.PARA: Does the Minister agree with the views of his colleague? Does he also agree that the mistake is about to be repeated and that it has been estimated by highly reputable economic forecasters that the result will add four percentage points to medium term interest rates? What will be the implications for investment and jobs of such an increase in interest rates?

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not agree with Senator Walsh, for all the reasons that were again exhaustively spelt out by Prime Minister Keating and Treasurer Dawkins two days ago in the House of Representatives. To have gone down the path described by Senator Walsh on the tax cuts issue would have been to guarantee unequivocally a blow-out in wages, with all the inflationary impact that would have flowed from that. It was a crucial element in the macro-economic management equation at the time to do as we did on tax cuts. Senator Walsh ought to know that, but he is a little bit unreconstructed on some of these issues. We have to live with that, but it does not govern Government policy. It did not then and it will not now.

PARA.TAB: Similarly any suggestion that there is any inevitability about interest rates increases of the kind Senator Short is describing is not a view to which the Government would subscribe. In the present macro-economic climate there is no reason whatsoever to make any such assumption.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that answer and would ask him a supplementary question. On the topic of interest rates does he agree with the views of the Treasury contained in documents tabled in the Parliament recently by the Government that interest rates will be lower under the coalition's Fightback proposals than would be the case if the Government's present policies were continued? If he does not agree with that, why does he not agree?
—I do not agree with that for the reasons that again have been spelt out by the Government's economic spokesmen on this particular issue.
—Why don't you admit you haven't got a clue about economics?

—We perfectly care about economics and we are doing remarkably better than those opposite in that respect. In an environment where the balance of payments has turned around quite fundamentally, producing figures which demonstrate that the exports of this country are dramatically expanding, particularly in the area of elaborately transformed manufactures, where this is not in any way a product of the recession, in a situation where inflation has come down to a measured rate of 1 1/2 per cent and an underlying rate of 3 1/2 per cent, in an environment where the economy has come out of recession, is moving back into growth and where we can expect 4 per cent growth this year, in an environment where a massive amount of micro-economic reform is taking place, in an environment where confidence has returned to the political equation and the Government and where the Opposition is absolutely on its knees with despair as a result, I can understand its wanting to engage in some diversionary manoeuvres of this kind, but there is no credibility in its position now and there never has been.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer to reports suggesting moves by the United States to list Australia as a country which pursues unfair trade practices. I ask the Minister: would he care to elaborate on comments he made to senior United States officials during his recent trip to the United States about American threats to retaliate against Australian rules for local content on our television?

—Senator Loosley would no doubt have seen a report in yesterday's newspapers suggesting that the United States trade representative, Carla Hills, released an indicative watch list of countries which the United States considered were costing its exporters millions of dollars. The report suggested that six pages of the report had been devoted to Australia's sins. This matter was raised with me by United States officials twice two weeks ago today. It was raised by firstly Barbara Franklin, who is the new United States Secretary of Commerce, and by Carla Hills's deputy as trade representative, Mr Moskow. They both suggested that if we were to proceed with any Australian content rules on pay television, they would be particularly horrified. They also suggested that our rules on advertising, even the recently liberalised ones, and our rules for Australian content quotas on free to air television now were in some way hindrances to their trade. I took particular offence to that line, given the real relationship between the two countries in trade overall, but particularly in film and television production.

PARA.TAB: I pointed out to both august United States representatives that we were generously allowed to compete for about 8 per cent of their sugar market and 2 per cent of their dairy market and no more. They were able to wage war on our wheat farmers in markets all around the world and even on the very question that they were raising with me, the United States provides about 80 per cent of Australian imports of television and film and there is, of course, only a tiny percentage of ours going over there. In fact, the trade deficit just on this one matter, that is film and television, is about $316m on the last available figures. So the United States, with its massive entertainment industry, is able to have a huge trade surplus with Australia on this one question, yet any attempt by Australia to have local content rules to make sure that our own identity, our own culture, is in some way protected will apparently bring about retaliation from the biggest brother.

It is worth noting that Australian drama—the centrepiece of local content rules—accounted for 597 hours out of 4,914 hours available across the three networks in 1988-89. So we are looking at only one-eighth of the time on drama being taken by Australian drama because of local content rules and the United States wants to tell us that it thinks that is too much. Anyone who has watched the latest cultural offering from the United States, a program called Studs, gets an idea of what we can get from the United States and what we are getting from it is anything but a fair deal. This is hypocrisy on a grand scale, not a small scale. I made it very clear to it that that was the view of not just the Government but of every thinking Australian.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. I remind the Minister of the guarantee he gave as Minister for Social Security on 5 June last year that, if unemployed people met their obligations under the Job Search activity test, no restriction would be placed on the number of hours of part time voluntary work they could do. I ask the Minister, firstly: is he aware that, despite his assurances, this is not how the Department is interpreting the legislation in practice and that unemployed people throughout the country are being threatened with the loss of their Job Search or Newstart allowances because they are allegedly doing too much voluntary work? Secondly, does the Minister think it is fair to continue to penalise unemployed people who are trying to help themselves and the community? Finally, when will the Government move to formally increase the number of hours of voluntary work unemployed people can undertake before their allowances are threatened?

—I recall a discussion on this matter last year, so I can certainly confirm that. Obviously, during a recession when unemployment numbers are very high, it is particularly important to allow for voluntary work and not to be overly harsh on those who participate in it, remembering always that the basic test for receipt of unemployment benefit is being available for full time work. I do not think one can undermine the test significantly, but certainly there is room at the margin for movement. I thought that movement had been occurring. I shall inquire from the Minister, Dr Blewett, whether or not it has been occurring and I will attempt to answer Senator Lees's question when the Senate resumes in two weeks time.
—I ask the Minister for Administrative Services: what would be the impact on Australia's overseas representation if the Overseas Property Group's budget were to be decreased by $20m?

—I have seen claims by the Opposition that savings of that magnitude could be made out of the Overseas Property Group's budget. In the Opposition's consumption tax package there is a claim that $20m can be saved out of that budget of $130m. Up until the last couple of days we have proceeded on the basis that those savings could have been made, as was indicated in the Fightback document, by the process of commercialisation or contracting out. The only problem has been—as I indicated two days ago—that, of the $130m budget for the Overseas Property Group, already $127m is contracted out to the private sector. So, if one believed the Fightback package, that degree of savings would have to be made out of an all-up sum of $3.3m. Obviously, that is impossible.

PARA.TAB: The day before yesterday Senator Parer put out a press statement saying that was not going to happen, that the $20m would be reduced from recurrent costs.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right.

—He now says that is right. If the Liberals by some chance get into power, there will be a reduction in the Overseas Property Group's budget of $20m. Leaving aside the basic inconsistency between Senator Parer's statement the day before yesterday and the Fightback document, and leaving aside the fact that the Opposition has ditched the approach it was going to take in this area of the commercialisation process reducing costs by $20m, let us allow the Opposition the indulgence of being able to cut $20m from the Overseas Property Group's budget by a reduction in running costs.

PARA.TAB: There are two problems with that, and I think the Senate ought to be aware of them. First of all, when one impacts on recurrent costs, one impacts on costs for which we have been committed and for which we are committed under legal obligation. Whether we are committed to residences, offices or whatever, we have contractual obligations. So, mechanically it is not that easy.

There is, however, another problem with the proposal, and that comes from the basic situation that the Opposition does not really understand what its proposal here entails. I am really sorry that Senator Hill is not at the table to listen to this, because it impacts directly on his shadow portfolio interests. If we were to cut the Overseas Property Group's budget by $20m, we would have to cut out 47 of our 74 overseas posts; that is, two-thirds of our representation overseas would have to be reduced. This would impact in a number of ways. Regionally, the Opposition would have to close posts in Fiji, Kiribati, Micronesia, Myanmar, New Caledonia, New Zealand, the Solomon Islands, Tonga, Vanuatu, and Vietnam.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is selectivity for you.

—Those opposite have a choice. Either they do something like this or they close down the UK and the US. I am sure that would not be on their priority list. The reality of their proposal would be this: close down regionally. South Africa would also have to be closed. I believe Senator Hill would find that very hard to justify, given the fact that it is the Opposition that has been clamouring to lift the remaining sanctions in respect of South Africa.
—Is that your option?

—Of course it is not my option. Basically, when those opposite are asking for the lifting of sanctions, their policy would lead to an effective break off of diplomatic relations. We would also have to close down our representation in the Vatican and Cambodia. This one is for Senator Boswell: a lot of the Middle East posts would have to be closed—Iran, Iraq, Jordan, Lebanon, Saudi Arabia, and Syria. What sort of impact would that have on our agricultural trade policies?

PARA.TAB: As well as that, Ireland would have to go, Senator McKiernan. As well, the post that is close to me, Cyprus, would have to go. This is the reality of an ill-thought-out policy. A $20m cutback on recurrent costs would mean 47 out of 74 posts, or two-thirds of our representation, would have to close. But we do have a couple of options, and I would not be so concerned if I were Senator Evans. We can either replace them with faxes and phones, or we could ask the British to represent us!

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industrial Relations to his answer to my question yesterday as to whether he would legislate to force contractors to operate within the award system. He gave an emphatic no. Four hours later the Minister released a press release stating that he would introduce legislation which in essence said that contractors and subcontractors would be brought under the jurisdiction of the AIRC. I ask: why did he mislead the Senate?

—I quite like Senator Crane's questions. I give him full marks for trying, but no marks for accuracy. Senator Crane asked me a specific question yesterday and he got a specific answer. The answer is right in every sense; it is correct in every sense. But if Senator Crane does not know what question he wishes to ask, he should not blame me if he gets the question wrong.

PARA.TAB: The Government has announced that there is a problem in industrial relations in this country that has been around for a long time. The problem is that there are some employers in Australia who want to tip people out of work, undercut the award rate, and introduce people in their place on so-called artificial and contrived contracts which style them as independent contractors. Therefore, for people working happily away under an award system, we find this unscrupulous practice of putting them out of work and replacing them with people who are genuinely covered by the award but who are on artificial contracts that get around the award. That creates industrial relations problems. This Government intends to provide the umpire, the Industrial Relations Commission, with the power—

TALK.START.PARA: —The mob you are sworn to wreck.
—Not to wreck. I am enlarging the powers so it can deal with this sort of dispute.
—Are they going to do it for nothing?
—Order! I ask the Minister to ignore the interjections or we will have a debate.

—Mr President, you are quite right. I will ignore the interjections. We are proposing to give the Industrial Relations Commission the power to decide, based on custom and practice, whether or not the area in dispute—if there is a dispute about this—is an area properly covered by the award or, on custom and practice, is traditionally an area of independent contracting.

PARA.TAB: The issue in dispute about whether or not jobs are being stolen from award based workers by independent contractors will be resolved. That is what we are proposing to do. It is in the public interest that that be done. That would remove an area of industrial disputes, if it were done. In addition to that—

TALK.START.PARA: —They are what you call sham contracts.

—Sham contracts, or artificial contracts—contracts that are contrived. There is no threat to genuine subcontractors in this, none at all. It does mean that in this shadow area where there is an overlap between awards and so-called independent contractors the Commission will have the power to determine, upon such an independent contractor initiating an application, whether a so-called contrived independent contract was in fact fair. So the umpire is installed to regulate an area of conflict, to remove that area of conflict from disputation and to lead it to settlement.

PARA.TAB: I might say that what clouds this debate is that both the MBA and HIA put out press releases yesterday of a highly excitable nature, apparently based on rumours they had heard. They never spoke to me about the issue before they put them out. It was a question of shoot first and ask questions later. When I saw these press releases I rang the HIA and I spoke to the executive director. I told him what the case was. I asked him to modify his position, based on the right information. I do not know whether he has done that. I certainly hope he does. It seems to me that there is a sense of the Wills by-election in the air and some people, in order to make a political point, are stirring up mischief to create an impression that housing prices might be doubled or tripled or quadrupled. The fact is that they are missing the point.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question. The Minister, in his press release yesterday, said, `The Commission can also determine whether the total remuneration of contractors', et cetera. That spells out quite clearly that the jurisdiction he is giving to the AIRC will cover all contractors, unless his press release is wrong. I ask: if the Minister is going to legislate against sham contractors, how does the Minister define `sham', and what is the relevant custom and practice to which the AIRC must have regard in disputes over independent contractors?

—I cannot anticipate what a sham contract might be, given all the permutations of a sham contract, just as the Taxation Commissioner cannot necessarily anticipate all the ways in which tax avoiders find loopholes in the Act. It is for that reason that I wish to clothe the Industrial Relations Commission with the power to look at the particular allegations about whether there is a sham contract or not; to examine the evidence in each particular case; and, based on that examination, and the hearing of the views of the parties, to make a decision whether the contract is a true contract or whether that contract is a sham contract. It is simply because no-one can anticipate the ingenuity of people in this area, and all of the permutations. It needs a case by case study and an independent inquiry based on the Commission to determine it. That is the answer to the first part of the supplementary question.

PARA.TAB: The second part of the supplementary question is: what is custom and practice in this case? Again, in each particular case it would be a question of examining the particular features of that industry or that area of employment. Since people in the housing industry knee jerked into a response before they had spoken to me about the matter yesterday, might I say that custom and practice in the housing industry, in the cottage industry, is by and large a question of subcontract labour. That industry is not by and large a province for award coverage.

If there is a matter of this character being brought before the Commission for determination, I imagine that the Commission will have regard to what is the prevailing custom and practice in that particular industry. If it were housing, that would be subcontractors, not awards. But in other areas the custom and practice may well be different. On a multi-storey construction site in the middle of the central business district of a capital city, custom and practice would be award coverage. Should people wish to then try to break that down by introducing sham contracts, the Commission would have regard to that area of award coverage and award against the so-called independent contractors.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation. Has the Minister seen overseas reports that the French Government has given Airbus Industrie one month to look at possible changes to the flying controls for the A320 airliner, which is used on domestic routes in Australia? Has he also seen reports that the highly regarded German airline Lufthansa has issued special leaflets addressing possible safety concerns about the A320? If so, what is his response to those matters?

—The matter has been of some concern to the Civil Aviation Authority in Australia and, of course, to Ansett Airlines. Following the recent Airbus A320 accident in France, I can assure honourable senators that the Australian Civil Aviation Authority has been in close touch with the French airworthiness authority, the manufacturer Airbus Industrie, and Ansett Airlines, which operates the A320 in Australia.

PARA.TAB: Already, Ansett, following advice from Airbus Industrie and with CAA endorsement, has specified operational procedures to its technical crew which are to be adopted during approach to land. The CAA has also confirmed that the French Government has instructed Airbus Industrie, as alluded to by Senator Maguire, to examine possible modifications to the man-machine interface associated with vertical flight guidance modes and the related operational procedures. Naturally, the CAA will continue to keep abreast of any developments in this area and will give consideration to mandatory action on any modifications that may arise from the Airbus Industrie study.

As a matter of interest—I have no doubt that honourable senators with an interest in this area, like Senator Maguire, will have recalled this—the preliminary report into the A320 accident issued by the French Accident Investigation Commission recommended the mandatory fitment of ground proximity warning systems to all French aircraft. This particular equipment, which was not fitted to the A320 which crashed, is already mandatory in Australia, including the fitment to Ansett's A320 aircraft.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. Is the Minister aware of the existence of a so-called medical smart card which allows patients' health records to be kept on a central computer and accessed by public servants? Will the Minister categorically deny that any such smart card or computer back-up system which gives government access to the medical history of all citizens of Australia is envisaged?

—Senator Herron's question seemed to float between an allegation that some sort of smart card existed and whether a smart card or some other computer operation was envisaged. It seems to me to be an unclear question; but in any case, I will seek an answer. But, of course, the Government has always in regard to these matters taken advice and put matters before the Privacy Commissioner, Mr Kevin O'Connor, in order to ensure that the sort of privacy safeguards which this Parliament and this Senate regard as so important, are indeed observed. In other words, nothing would be done by the Government which in any way went against the information privacy principles which have been endorsed by this Parliament.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. My question was quite straightforward and simple: does a computer back-up system which gives access to the medical history of citizens exist?
—That was not the question. I have already indicated the general policy of the Government, and I will seek any further information that might be appropriate.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Has the Minister seen reports this morning that UN aid has been cut off from refugees in camps on the Thai-Cambodian border? What is the truth of these reports? Is the Australian Government concerned by the information coming through?

—The reports are not so much that aid has been cut off generally to the refugees in the camps but, rather, that it has been cut off from Cambodians newly arriving in those displaced persons camps along the Thai-Cambodian border.There has been concern about the number of Cambodians moving to these camps over recent days in order to benefit from the resettlement aid to be offered under the repatriation program organised by the UN High Commissioner for Refugees. Under that program, provision had been made for resettlement in Cambodia of more than 350,000 displaced Cambodians from the camps, and each family of repatriates will receive funds, building materials and other assistance to help their resettlement in Cambodia.

PARA.TAB: We do not yet have any confirmation of the reported decision by the UNHCR to suspend assistance to new arrivals in the border camps, but it is perfectly possible that such a decision has been made in order to avoid a kind of revolving door situation developing. I am confident that the UNHCR officials on the ground are best placed to judge the best way to deal with this particular problem.

I emphasise again that the suggestions seem to relate only to new arrivals. The decision certainly does not affect progress on the present implementation phase of the repatriation program, which did begin very successfully with the first returns to Cambodia two or three days ago—on 30 March.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, and, like Senator Loosley's question to Senator Richardson, I also refer to the US Government report this week that names Australia, along with 42 other countries, as erecting unfair trade barriers against American products. Carla Hill's statement refers to Australia's distortions and barriers, including tariff levels, customs, valuation practices, government procurement practices, export subsidies and incentives, shortcomings in the protection of intellectual property rights, and so on. I also refer to the Prime Minister's somersault on tariff policy in the Wills by-election campaign undermining Australia's credibility at this crucial final stage of the GATT negotiations. Can the Minister imagine any worse time for Australia to take a stand in favour of protection when for years now in the Cairns Group we have urged Europe and the US to significantly lower protection?

—We have not taken a stand in favour of protection; we have just taken a stand against zero protection of the kind that is being advocated by the Opposition. The protection that we are talking about is one that after 1996 will amount on products generally to an average rate of five per cent, which will amount to 15 per cent so far as the automobile industry is concerned by the year 2000, and will amount to 25 per cent maximum so far as TCF is concerned. It is a 5, 15, 25 set of rates that we are talking about, as distinct from the zero, zero, zero rates that are being proposed in a scorched earth fashion by the Opposition. That is the difference between the Opposition and the Government. It is a difference, when you look at it in the larger context, that is at the margin of the debate about protection because the Government's anti-protectionist credentials are and will remain absolutely impeccable. We are the Government that has succeeded in bringing down rates very dramatically from the absurdly high and counterproductive levels that were being maintained through the Opposition's years of government. We are the Government that is getting rid of quotas completely from all areas of industry sectors by 1993. We are the Government that has made a dramatic series of endeavours to bring down the protective barriers that have existed and have reduced the competitive efficiency of the Australian economy. Nothing that the Prime Minister or anyone else has said has cut across that.

PARA.TAB: As to the reports coming out of the United States, let me say this. The US trade representative is required by US legislation to furnish reports each year to Congress identifying practices in specific economic sectors which it regards as preventing US companies from receiving fair access to the markets of its trading partners. These reports are designed essentially to assist the US Administration in developing its trade negotiating priorities over the coming year. The report claims, as Senator Teague has said, that Australia maintains unfair trade barriers against US products, particularly in the areas of broadcasting, which was the subject of Senator Richardson's earlier discussion, intellectual property and government procurement.

These are claims that we have contested, and contested vigorously. They were contested vigorously and very effectively by Senator Richardson when he was in the United States recently. They were contested vigorously when John Kerin was in Washington on 19 and 20 March. They were contested vigorously in senior officials' exchanges which took place a few days later—on 26 March. We will continue to contest these claims vigorously at all available opportunities.

It is a matter of concern to us that Australia, with our strong record of trade reform, to which I have already referred, should be targeted by the United States, a country which enjoys enormous trading opportunities in Australia with a bilateral trade surplus of 2 : 1 running in its favour, and a country many of whose own trade practices in areas of crucial importance to this country—particularly in agriculture, where the entry of beef, sugar and dairy products to the United States market is subject to restrictions—are unquestionably unfair.

There is only so much that we can put up with by way of double standards from the United States. We do not accept these kinds of allegations lying down. I have made that clear, Senator Richardson has made it clear, Mr Kerin has made it clear, the Prime Minister has made it clear—and I do not think that anyone in the United States will be in any doubt about that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade barely disguises his embarrassment over the fact that this signal comes in the final weeks before the GATT negotiations conclude. Is it true that the Minister has complained to the Prime Minister that this signal is upsetting Australia's position in the GATT negotiations? Does the Minister endorse the statements that have been made on tariff policy by the Prime Minister?
—The only signal that the Prime Minister has given in recent days is that you mob are going to be decimated in Wills.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Nuclear Accidents on Vessels in Ports

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. I refer to the United States Navy operating instruction No. 3040.5B, obtained under the United States Freedom of Information Act by a New Zealand academic, Dr Peter Wills, which sets out the procedures to be followed by the United States Navy in the event of a nuclear reactor accident on a warship in port. I ask: firstly, is the Minister aware that the United States Navy's procedures are designed to cope with an uncontained core meltdown, in contrast to Australian port safety plans, which are based on the much more benign contingency of a contained meltdown? Secondly, is he aware that United States procedures require evacuation zones to be set according to measured radiation levels and could extend to a distance of miles, whereas Australian plans limit the zone of immediate evacuation to a 600-metre radius? Thirdly, is he aware that the United States Navy requires tugs to be available within one hour of the accident if towing of the stricken vessel is required, whereas Australian plans provide for towing to occur up to 24 hours later? Finally, what action does he propose to take in view of these discrepancies?
—Some of these questions are far too long.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The safety issues involved in visits to Australia by nuclear-powered and nuclear-armed warships have been the subject of an inquiry conducted by the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. This inquiry produced a comprehensive report, which was tabled in this chamber in August 1989. The Committee endorsed the judgments made by successive Australian governments about the safety issues involved in visits by allied warships. In fact, the Committee concluded:

ANSWER.PARA: There was very persuasive evidence that the probability of any accident involving the significant release of radiation during a visit to an Australian port is extremely small.
It should be noted for the record that the US Navy has never had a nuclear weapon accident in any port, either in the US or elsewhere.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. The burden of my question was precisely the discrepancies between the report of our inquiry and the far more realistic instructions of the US Navy. In view of these discrepancies, is the Minister prepared to order a moratorium on nuclear-powered warship visits and a thorough review of port safety planning, in the light of his Department's gross underestimation of the risks and consequences of such an accident?
—No.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. The Minister will be aware that the One Nation statement indicated that any surplus from the sale of wool from stockpiles by the Australian Wool Realisation Commission would be refunded to those who paid the 12 per cent wool tax this season. This was confirmed by the Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, in an answer to a question last Thursday. However, it has been reported that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy is now favouring the position of the Opposition and the wool industry—that is, to reduce the tax to below 10 per cent next season—and not the refund arrangement that the Prime Minister announced. What is the Government's position now? Is it Mr Crean's position, Mr Dawkins's position or the Prime Minister's position?

PARA.TAB: I am well aware that the Minister has also been told of this because Transport contacted the same sources that I did. I will be most interested in the Minister's answer. Is he going to change it from `less than one per cent', or what percentage does the Minister now claim applies?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to respond very briefly to provide Senator Walters with some additional information. One does not have to be an expert on waterfront or shipping to realise that the assertion that of the freight charge for shipping a container from Australia to London—a sea journey of 12,000 miles—60 per cent would be land-based charges is pretty extraordinary.
—That is the problem. You are just starting to get the point.

—Let me finish, Senator Hill. I will be brief. The reason that Transport contacted the source is that, out of courtesy to Senator Walters or any senator who asks questions in here, I try to get the most complete answer that I can. I have some additional information which I will now provide. It needs to be made clear that comparisons of shipping freight rates—and that was the problem; not the waterfront stevedoring charges—such as these are fraught with difficulties, as I have pointed out to the Senate many times before. Great care needs to be taken to ensure that like is compared with like, as I have also pointed out many times before.

PARA.TAB: Freight charges are struck as a result of commercial negotiation between the customer and the shipping company. As a result of that commercial negotiation, the rates will vary very significantly in this industry—and they do—even for similar containers over the same route, for any number of reasons, including seasonal demands on shipping space, the relative level of shipping services and the overall balance of exports and imports.

The cost of moving a container from Hobart to Brisbane cannot readily be compared with the cost of moving a similar container to Tilbury in England. For a start, there is no direct shipping service from Hobart to Brisbane, and the cost, whichever route is taken, will include significant elements of land transport charges; that is, from Hobart to Brisbane, not from Hobart to Tilbury in England. Information supplied by my Department suggests that the $2,000 quote to Tilbury is low. The charge quoted from Hobart to Brisbane is more difficult to judge, as it includes significant land transport movements. Using the most direct shipping service, Hobart to Sydney, the average wharf-to-wharf charge is currently around $1,375. The container would then need to be transferred by either road or rail to Brisbane. If the quote is accurate, $2,100 of the charge could represent the land transport component or other ancillary charges.

It needs to be made clear that very little of the overall charge in either of these cases, or indeed the difference between them, has anything to do, as I said yesterday, with the cost of stevedoring. Stevedoring represents a small proportion of the total freight charge. The average stevedoring charge in Australia currently, because of the significant reduction, of somewhere near 30 per cent in the last 12 months in this charge, is now somewhere between $180 and $200 per container.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—The Minister has deliberately attempted to muddy the waters by referring to the Hobart-Brisbane trek. He has not repeated his claim that the land charges on the Hobart-London trek are less than one per cent.

While we on this side of the chamber have become used to the Minister doing that, I am extremely concerned to ensure that the Australian people understand that when the Minister does not tell the truth in this place and the evidence is brought to him—

—Well, he is misleading the Senate. The people of Australia need to understand that when he is misleading the Senate, and evidence is given to him that he has indeed misled the Senate, he will still not acknowledge that the percentage figure he gave the Senate yesterday is totally wrong. That, I believe, is extremely irresponsible. The Government should correct the Minister and make him tell this Senate the facts behind the question.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the personal explanation of the Minister for Shipping and Aviation (Senator Collins).

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister definitely misled the Senate. He is about to get up and walk out of the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have two meetings stacked up, one on the other.

—I do not care what meetings the Minister has got. This is much more important. The Minister should not run away; this is much more important. The Minister is running out of the Senate because he has to go to some other meeting. Apparently the Senate is not as important as the meetings the Minister has to go to.
—That would be right.

—I hear Senator Faulkner saying, `That's right'; the Senate is not as important as the meetings the Minister has to go to. Senators ought to take note of that. PARA.TAB: The fact that the transponder is not sending a signal from that aircraft is totally irrelevant, as we tried to interject on the Minister when he was giving the answer, and he then alleged that we were fools for suggesting it.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was right. You are a fool. You are a complete fool.
—Order!

—He was saying that he had told us that the problem was the transponder. The transponder is nothing. The problem was the software—as he has finally admitted today—in the radar equipment on the ground. That aircraft was circling in that area without the radar system on the ground having any bleep of that aircraft. This is Australia. Do we understand how dangerous that was? Then the Minister said that because we raised this matter, we are frightening the people. The people have a right to be frightened. This is one of the most important matters that have been brought up in this Senate for a long time: aircraft are flying around Australia without being recognised by the radar system. The Minister misled the Parliament and misled the people out there, and then accused us of raising the matter unfairly, improperly, or in some other way.

PARA.TAB: This Minister has misled the Senate repeatedly on these issues of safety in relation to aircraft flying around our skies in Australia. It is time that his colleagues in Cabinet took him to task and made him make the CAA do something about it. We cannot allow this dangerous mechanism to continue the way it has been under the lack of control of this Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must comment on the irresponsibility of a Minister who attacks one of his own colleagues and then runs from the chamber. What Senator Lewis is talking about is a very important point. With respect to the allegations by Senator Collins, if he had taken the trouble to read Hansard yesterday—because once more he was not in the chamber when matters which vitally affected him were raised—he would have seen that what I said was that he gave an incomplete answer. I did not say that he categorically misled the House. Later on I said, `To that extent, namely with respect to his transponder argument, he certainly misled the Senate'. How it is written up in the paper is not my concern.

PARA.TAB: The basic point is this: in any modern air traffic control radar system there is a primary radar which detects and shows the presence of aircraft; there is an SSR, a secondary surveillance radar, which interrogates an instrument in the aircraft, the transponder, and it identifies that particular aircraft. It appears—and this is a very important point—that there is a basic fault in the Thomson-CSF systems. The fault is that when four zeros are set on the transponder, or if perhaps the transponder has some faults in it—in other words, the pilot sets the code he is asked to set and a different signal is transmitted—this brilliant Thomson system—

TALK.START.PARA: —Shuts off.

—It tells the signal coming in from the secondary surveillance radar to ignore the primary surveillance signal that an aircraft is present, and indicates that there is no aircraft there. The aircraft then becomes invisible on the radar screen. The system that Senator Collins and the CAA have bought for us—the radar systems provided by Thomson-CSF and installed now at Cairns, Coolangatta, Mount Macedon and Gellibrand—all have this basic flaw in their systems. Apparently the new TAAATS system of Thomson-CSF, which will be an Australia-wide system, similarly has this flaw in it.

PARA.TAB: That raises some very important points. The first is, despite what Senator Collins says, very exhaustive checks were made, not only of that F28 aircraft but three Qantas 767s which also were invisible. No mechanical or electronic fault was shown in those aircraft. The second very important point is that the F28 and the three Qantas Boeing 767s, within a short space of time, both preceding and after the Cairns event, flew through one or all of Darwin, Brisbane and Sydney airspaces. The radar systems in Darwin, Sydney and Brisbane are all very old hat. They are at least 20 years old. Yet all those aircraft flew through and were correctly identified on the radar screens by the air traffic controllers at those airfields at the time with the air traffic control radars. So it is a reasonable presumption that there was not a fault with the transponders in those aircraft.

Let us look at the significance of it. If Senator Collins has bought a system where one can dial up four zeros on a transponder and become invisible, or get a pretence or a presentation of invisibility on the air traffic control radars, what a bonus it is for drug runners coming into Australia. They just have to dial up four zeros on the transponder, and fly into Cairns with invisibility—as we know drug runners are doing in north Australia at present. Think of all the billions of dollars the Americans could save on their stealth technology with their defence aircraft if they had a radar system in the hands of the enemy with that sort of nonsense.

The other argument that is advanced by Senator Collins and his people is the fact that some of these aircraft, like the Boeing 767, have two radar aerials for their transponders; one on top of the aircraft and one on the bottom of the aircraft. They say, `Well, you get interference with the propagation of the radar signal'. Again the evidence is against that. Boeing 767s have been in extensive use around the world for about 10 years. The problem has not appeared anywhere other than at Cairns and Coolangatta. In this particular case the aircraft flew through Sydney, Brisbane and Darwin and there was no problem at all.

I bring this fact to Senator Collins's attention because he will never bring it to the attention of the Senate: the great Thomson-CSF system at Cairns, which has a recorded history of something like 23 or 26 significant failures since it was installed and which, of course, is 20 months over time on its installation, on three days in the last month had significant shutdown times.

On 25 March the primary radar was shut down for 4 hours 55 minutes while the magnetron was replaced, and it was replaced because when the system was bought the CAA accepted the Thomson-CSF proposition that it be a magnetron rather than a kylstron, which is at the heart of the radar system, the transmitter. On the next day, 26 March, the primary radar was shut down for 1 hour 26 minutes. On the third day, 27 March, the primary radar was shut down for a motor change for three minutes. That is a total of three shutdowns in three consecutive days totalling 6 hours 24 minutes, and all this from a new radar installation which was supposed to meet a requirement of four minutes down time per calendar year.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

The Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee has been actively pursuing the task set by the Senate to inquire into Australia's relations with the republics of Latin America. One hundred and twenty submissions have been received and eleven public hearings held, including hearings in Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane and Adelaide as well as Canberra.

It was obvious to the Committee from the very beginning of the inquiry that it had been given a very substantial task. The terms of reference are wide-ranging as the Committee is required in effect to look at every aspect of the relationship between Australia and Latin America, a region that encompasses over 20 countries. Even focussing on the major republics in the region has meant looking at the many and various aspects of Australia's relations with eight or so countries. As material before the Committee was studied and examined, new witnesses were approached for further information on a significant number of issues.

The Committee has already begun intensive work on the draft of the report and has approved four chapters already, while still awaiting further evidence on some issues. In fact, only this morning the Committee held what will probably be the last of the public hearings with the Ambassador of Peru. There are still a number of important issues that require close and detailed consideration before the report can be finalised. New information still is being received.

The Committee has come to the conclusion that it should seek a further extension of time to report. The Committee is confident that an extension to mid-June will enable the Committee to do full justice to the important task before it.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances I give notice that, 15 sitting days after today, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to make a short statement about the Committee's concerns with these instruments.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the instruments provides extensive safeguards for persons who elect to pay an administrative fine for an offence rather than have the matter dealt with by a court. However, there is no provision for persons affected to be notified of these safeguards, which may mean the difference between, on the one hand, paying a fine of $200 and not having a conviction recorded or being convicted and, on the other, paying a fine of $1,000 or being sentenced to imprisonment for six months.

PARA.TAB: Another instrument provides for garnishee of wages, salaries and bank accounts with no immediate indication of appropriate safeguards. The third instrument provides for appointments to an important statutory authority to be terminated `at the pleasure of the Minister'. The Committee will seek an explanation of these apparently defective provisions.
I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a statement of the concerns of the Committee.
Leave granted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Fisheries Management Regulations Statutory Rules 1992 No. 20

SPEECH.PARA: These Regulations implement administrative details of the Fisheries Management Act 1991, providing for the administration of fishing concessions, operation of boats and equipment and surveillance and enforcement.

The Regulations provide for certain offences to be dealt with by an administrative fine, rather than a penalty imposed by a court, in the same way that numbers of minor traffic offences, such as parking, are dealt with. If a member of the public elects to pay an administrative fine then the Regulations properly provide extensive and adequate safeguards. These are that the person's liability in relation to the offence is taken to be discharged, further proceedings cannot be taken against the person and the person is not to be regarded as having been convicted of the offence.

However, the beneficial effect of these appropriate safeguards may not be enjoyed by persons accused of offences, as there is no provision for them to be informed of these rights. An entire regulation prescribes what must be included in infringement notices sent to persons affected, but this does not include notification of these valuable safeguards. The Committee considers that personal rights are only effective if properly communicated. In this case it would appear that such notification rights are essential.

In the present case the matter is particularly important because of a great disparity in penalties. The administrative fine for any offence cannot exceed $200, yet the penalties imposed by a court for the same offences range from, in one case, a fine of $500, in six cases a fine of $1,000 and in an unspecified number of possible cases imprisonment for six months.

The Committee has also given a notice of disallowance in respect of similar provisions in the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) (Modifications of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918) Regulations, Statutory Rules 1991 No. 397, relating to failure to vote in elections.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Ministerial Guidelines Under s.44 of the Student Assistance Act 1973

SPEECH.PARA: These Guidelines relate to management of debts due to the Commonwealth in respect of student assistant schemes. Although the instrument is called Guidelines, the parent Act requires that these be observed by the Minister and other officers. The concerns of the Committee relate to personal liberties, appropriate review rights and legal validity.

Many of the Guidelines grant important discretions. Thus, there are provisions for an officer to review an objection to a withholding from an entitlement. There is also provision for a debtor to satisfy the Department of a matter within seven days. Another provision appears to grant a discretion as to whether failure to pay a debt was the fault of the debtor. There are other discretions to write off a debt entirely, to waive a debt, and to approve repayment by instalments.

Most of these discretions provide criteria for their exercise. However, these criteria themselves include other discretions. Some discretions are subject to presumably internal review. However, there is no indication whether any of these discretions are subject to merits review by an independent tribunal.

Some of the discretions have serious implications for personal rights. Thus, one provision is that a section of the Act may be used to garnishee deductions from salary or wages or from an account at a bank or other financial institution. In this case the Committee would wish to be satisfied that the provision is justified by the parent Act and that there are appropriate safeguards for a person affected, including independent review of the merits of any action.

The Guidelines only relate to the exercise of powers under the parent Act. That Act includes extensive review provisions and it may be that the discretions in these Guidelines are included in decisions made under the Act and are subject to such review. However, the Committee would wish to receive express confirmation of this.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Guidelines HSB 3/1992 under s.82F of the National Health Act 1953

SPEECH.PARA: These Guidelines, among other things, provide for the appointment of the Commissioner, other members and deputies to the Private Health Insurance Administration Council. This is a statutory body with important functions and wide powers. The PHIAC is also a body corporate, which may hold and dispose of personal property and may sue and be sued in its corporate name.

The Guidelines provide that the period of appointment shall be "at the pleasure of the Minister". Although such expressions were used in the past, the Committee now regards them as archaic and generally inappropriate. Such appointees should be only removed for proven misbehaviour or physical, mental or other forms of incapacity. The Committee is always vigilant to protect personal rights and liberties. In this case the personal reputations of persons could suffer if they were removed without reasonable cause. This would be particularly serious for appointees to the PHIAC who presumably will be eminent people. In this context the Committee noted that the Commissioner may be appointed on a full-time basis. On its face, it is not acceptable for a full-time Commissioner of an important statutory authority, together with all of his or her members and deputies, to hold office at the pleasure of the Minister. In addition, the independence of action of the appointees would appear to be compromised.
The Committee believes that it may be appropriate to obtain an undertaking to amend the Guidelines to meet its concerns.

Dear Senator Giles

I refer to your letter of 28 February 1992 to the Minister for Transport and Communications concerning the VHF High Band Frequency Band Plan (148 to 174 MHz), Statutory Rules 1991 No.354, and the VHF Mid Band Frequency Band Plan (70 to 87.5 MHz), Statutory Rules 1991 No.355, considered by the Committee at its meeting of 27 February 1992.
2. The Minister has asked me to respond on his behalf particularly as it was I who made the Plans on behalf of the Minister.
3. As you have observed, both Plans are very similar in content and wording, and the following comments in relation to the Committee's concerns about the Plans relate generally to both Plans.
The making of Frequency Band Plans

4. The Radiocommunications Act 1983 (The Act) establishes the statutory framework for management of the radio frequency spectrum in Australia. A key element in the Act relates to the making of frequency band plans. Band planning is the mechanism by which spectrum allocation can be adjusted to provide additional capacity for both new and existing services. The process of making band plans has been adopted as a means of coordinating changes in spectrum usage in a manner which provides for the maximum amount of consultation with users and which avoids the need for achieving change through the abrupt cancellation or non-renewal of licences.

5. The statutory requirements for public consultation in sections 19 and 20 of the Act are really minimum requirements and in practice it is necessary to have a far more extensive process of consultation throughout the development of new band plans. The making of the VHF plans was the culmination of about three years of development involving a number of intermediate levels of consultation with industry and users. The formal gazetting for full public comment in May 1991, in accordance with the Act, was the final step in the consultation process. It resulted in a number of significant changes, particularly in regard to minimising changeover costs to existing users.
Decision-making context of the Plans

6. Before specifically addressing the Committee's concerns about the Plans, I would like to make some comments on the decision-making context in which the Plans operate. The two main types of decisions made under the Act where a decision-maker will refer to the Plans are:
(i)under section 24 and subsection 25(1) of the Act, when deciding whether or not to grant a transmitter licence authorising a person to operate a transmitter on a particular frequency; and

(ii)under subsection 25(3) of the Act, when deciding whether or not to vary a condition of a transmitter licence by changing the frequency on which the licensee is authorised to operate a transmitter.

7. It is relevant to note that paragraph 24(2)(c) of the Act provides that in exercising his or her licensing powers, the Minister shall have regard to whether or not he or she is satisfied that the proposed operation of the transmitters is in accordance with the appropriate frequency band plan. Also, paragraph 25(1)(a) provides that a transmitter licence is subject to the condition that the holder of the licence shall not operate, or permit the operation of, the transmitter except for a purpose specified in the licence, being a purpose not inconsistent with a purpose of a kind specified in the appropriate frequency band plan under subsection 19(2).
8. Decisions made under section 24 and 25 of the Act are subject to internal departmental review and subsequent review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal by virtue of section 86 of the Act.

9. Other decisions made with reference to the Plans relate to test permits (section 10), frequency reservation certificates (section 21), and temporary permits (section 35). All these decisions are similarly subject to review under section 86 of the Act.

10. It is important to note that all operative decisions made with reference to the Plans are made under one of the abovementioned sections of the Act (the `substantive' powers)—none are actually made under the Plans themselves. Where the Plans provide for discretions on divergence from the purposes for which any particular segment of the radio frequency spectrum may be used, those discretions are actually exercised under one of the above sections. The Plans in themselves do not create any new non-reviewable discretions.
Clause 7(3)—criteria for allowing different channelling arrangements

11. In your letter, you mention that the criteria, which may be taken into account in exercising the discretion of whether to allow channelling arrangements other than as provided for in the Plans, are set out in a Note which does not appear to be part of the Plans. You also comment that there is no indication of who is to exercise this discretion.

12. Taking your second comment first, those officers in the Department who are delegates of the Minister in relation to the `substantive' powers of the Act will be the officers who may exercise the discretion when exercising those powers.

13. In relation to your first comment, the criteria set out in the Note are meant as a guide only, without intending to limit the range of matters which may be relevant to considering whether a proposal would provide for more efficient use of the spectrum. It is expected that in each individual case, the particular circumstances of that case are considered in deciding whether to exercise the discretion. As the discretion is exercised as part of the exercise of a reviewable `substantial' power under the Act, should an affected person consider that an irrelevant consideration has been taken into account, or that a relevant consideration has not been taken account, that person would have a right of review under section 86 of the Act.
Clause 9(3)—exemption from clauses 6 and 7

14. In your letter, you comment that there is no indication of the relevant criteria for, or procedures for the exercise of, the discretion to provide a temporary exemption from clauses 6 and 7 of the Plans.

15. You will note that subclause 3(3) of the Plans provides that wherever `authorised' is used in the Plans, this refers to an authorisation given by the Secretary of the Department, or by an officer of the Department authorised in writing by the Secretary, for the relevant purpose. It is intended that the `authorised officers' will be the more senior delegates of the Minister for the purposes of the `substantive' powers under the Act.

16. Subclause 9(3) makes it clear that temporary exemptions under this clause may only be granted for the purpose of facilitating implementation of the Plans. As there are many services which are affected by the Plans, it is impossible to anticipate at this time the detailed movements of services in each city or State which will be necessary in order to meet the conversion dates set out in the Plans. As you noted in your statement to the Senate on 3 March 1992, the General Note in clause 2 of the Plans sets out measures to minimise the impact of the cost and disruption for users in converting to compliance with the Plans. These measures are meant as a guide to the decision-makers in each State and Territory exercising the `substantive' powers in the Act.

17. It is relevant to note that subclause 9(3) is in a very similar form to subclause 11(4) of the Radiocommunications-Australian Spectrum Plan, Statutory Rules 1990 No.413, which provides that, subject to subclause 11(1) of that Plan, each frequency band may be used by services other than those identified in the Spectrum Plan on a transitional basis to facilitate new or revised allocations of frequency bands.
Note 6, page 9 of Statutory Rules 1991 No.354
18. In your letter, you comment that Note 6 appears to be legislative in character, and appears to give a discretion to the Secretary or to an officer authorised by the Secretary.

19. You will note that Items 14 and 19 of Table 2 refer the reader to Note 6. In so far as Note 6 has any substantive effect, it can only operate in the context of an exercise of one of the substantive (and reviewable) powers under the Act. Those notes which are included as a guide and are not operative provisions of the Plans are identified by being enclosed in square brackets.
20. Again, the discretion is subject to review under section 86 of the Act.
Notes 3 and 5, page 11 of Statutory Rules 1991 No.354

21. In your letter, you refer to Notes 3 and 5, and comment that they provide for discretions but do not appear to provide for review of those discretions. I assume you were referring to those Notes on page 11 of Statutory Rules 1991 No.354.
22. I refer you to my comments in paragraphs 6—10 and 15 above.
Clause 4—conversion dates—General Notes 4 and 8

23. In your letter, you ask whether the discretion to compel a user to convert before the relevant conversion date is authorised by the Act, and whether there is any review of each a compulsion decision.
24. Again I refer you to my comments in paragraphs 6—10 above.
Conclusion

25. I trust that the above comments meet the Committee's concerns. It may be helpful if the General Notes in the Plans were amended to include a message to the effect that the notes are intended as a guide to decision-makers when making decisions under the Act. I understand such a change would not require compliance with the extended consultation procedures for making frequency band plans required by sections 19 and 20 of the Act, because the General Notes are not part of the provisions of the Plans. I would be happy to make myself and officers of my Department available to meet with the Committee to further discuss the matter should the Committee so desire.
Yours sincerely
Warren Snowdon
Parliamentary Secretary to the
Minister for Transport and Communications
