This reference was one of two given to the Committee relating to services for people with disabilities; the first of these reports, Accommodation for People with Disabilities, was tabled in May 1990. The inquiry into the reference on employment predated that report and hearings extended over the period early 1989 to late 1990.

Over that time, there have been considerable changes in service provision and in development of new services. The Commonwealth/State Disability Agreement, signed in mid-1991, has clarified the respective Commonwealth and State/Territory responsibilities, with accommodation and related services being provided by the States, and employment services being a Commonwealth responsibility. This reflects the belief of many witnesses that it is essential for employment services for people with disabilities to be operated by the Commonwealth, which has the major responsibility for employment and labour-market programs.

Many witnesses also believed that departments such as the Department of Employment, Education and Training (DEET) ought to assume responsibility for all employment options for people with disabilities in order to move away from the suggestion that people with disabilities should be assisted by Health and Community Services departments. The Committee has not supported this idea in full. Its evaluation of DEET programs has led to its concluding that, while the Department has established many useful programs, the value of these to people with disabilities, and particularly to people with severe disabilities, needs to be carefully assessed. The Committee acknowledges the development by DEET of a Disability Strategy and of special units such as Disability Access Support Units (DASUs), and believes that these may provide valuable support to people with disabilities. Nonetheless, it has concluded that the transfer of employment options from the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services to the Department of Employment, Education and Training would not be in the best interests of people with disabilities for some time.

One of the reasons for this is the difficulty faced by generic services in meeting the wide range of needs of people with disabilities. This has been a difficult issue for the Committee, but I believe it has been addressed through proper consideration being given to a wide range of factors that must necessarily impact upon access to services and the extent to which services can provide opportunities for people with disabilities. Because this area is one which has been the subject of division and debate for a number of years, it was essential for the Committee to stand back and look at many of the attitudes which have influenced those involved. These include service providers, consumers, parent groups, advocates, and government departments. Much evidence presented to the Committee argued passionately for and against a number of different service types, and discussed in detail the problems with service provision and differing philosophies and experiences.It was clear that the issue was of profound concern to a substantial number of people. It also became clear that, in many instances, there was little available information on a number of important issues and that this affected the extent to which people with disabilities had access to services, and to services which were appropriate.

In placing services within a broad context, the Committee considered the availability of data and of uniform terminology. It found that absence of comprehensive data, including data on school leavers ready to enter the workforce, was still a major problem. The Committee acknowledges the development within departments of new data collections, including those which will help assess the need for services. Nonetheless, the Committee is sufficiently concerned about data and definition problems to have made a number of recommendations in the first chapter about the need for improved data collection and the development of uniform definitions. This would help towards an assessment of unmet need.

In considering the broad context of employment options, the Committee was also concerned to identify issues of access and equity which it believed were not sufficiently taken into consideration in the planning of services or in the evaluation of successful service operation. Consequently, the Committee has referred in the second chapter to a number of factors which it believes could seriously affect access. These factors include socio-economic background, gender, culture and race, geographic location and age. The Committee believes that it is essential for funding departments and service providers to be aware of such issues, particularly insofar as they may seriously affect the awareness of individuals or groups as to the need for, and the existence of, services. Consequently, the Committee has emphasised these matters, including the need for research on factors other than disability which may limit access to services.

The issue of access and of equity has also been examined. Much of the evidence received by the Committee spoke of the negative perceptions held by some people in the community about people with disabilities, of the need for changes to legislation, of the importance of education and information programs, in order to establish a legal base for change and to change community attitudes about the extent to which people with disabilities could contribute to society through work and other activities. The Committee supports the proposed Commonwealth anti-discrimination legislation and has made recommendations concerning types of discrimination which should be addressed and the need for affirmative action principles. Recommendations have also been made about continued information and education programs.

One of the major concerns expressed by witnesses was the need to create a positive image for people with disabilities, and for employers and government departments to become more aware of the importance of positive attitudes and of taking into account the particular needs of people with disabilities. However, it also believes there is room for improvement, particularly in the public sector, which is often seen as failing to live up to its own message through providing new employment options for people with disabilities. Again, while acknowledging gradual improvements in the public sector as an employing body, the Committee notes that it is essential for bodies such as the Australian Public Service to set an example. While a diverse economic structure, multiskilling, workplace reform and rapid technological change may have meant a restructuring of industry which can lead to shrinking job opportunities, the same factors may also contribute to the creation of increased job opportunities for people with severe disabilities as well as for those with mild to moderate disabilities.

Many witnesses argued that access to education was crucial to later effective access to meaningful employment, and regarded access to mainstream school education as the best option for many children with disabilities. The Committee was particularly concerned to examine the transition from school to the workforce since this was identified as a major factor in determining an individual's success in obtaining satisfactory employment and in retaining skills. Again, the issue of data was raised, and it appeared that no adequate statistics were available Australia-wide on the numbers and needs of those who left school each year and how far such needs could be met. While it is obvious that a number of factors will affect access to appropriate education and to transition services, the Committee believes that such services are crucial and that governments and other education authorities must give top priority to identifying needs, providing work experience, setting up effective transition services, and establishing referral and counselling services which ensure that students do not miss out on employment opportunities and access to other community activities.

Although the Committee has placed particular emphasis on the importance of equity in access to school education and to transition programs, it also believes that tertiary education has a major role to play. Both TAFE and universities provide opportunities for people with disabilities, but in many cases the lack of adequate resources, and difficulties of access, meant that individuals with the ability to take advantage of opportunities were more frustrated than assisted. The Committee has made recommendations, including a recommendation on annual reporting by tertiary institutions, on access of people with disabilities to education services.

The Committee believes that its examination of a range of access factors has provided a solid basis for its evaluation of current and future employment options. Its objective was to see how these options operated, whose needs they met, how they could be improved, and whether they addressed the concerns voiced by many witnesses. Such concerns emphasised, in particular, the fact that too often 'employment' was seen as a full-time occupation for people who, while initially requiring assistance in accessing employment and in learning additional skills, would nonetheless demonstrate consistent skill maintenance or improvement. Yet, as a number of submissions pointed out, consistent upward progression and increasing development of skills was not possible for all people with disabilities, nor was full-time employment. The effects of different disabilities were therefore considered in order to determine the range of needs and the types of services which might be needed.

The Committee has emphasised that standard full-time employment options cannot be utilised by a number of individuals; and, while it acknowledges that some options are available which can meet the demand for part-time work or job-sharing, believes that a priority should be to develop further employment options.

In particular, the Committee has considered the need for more flexible concepts of employment to be developed which would include work, study, recreation, etc. Such options may be of considerable benefit to the community. For people whose skills may decrease rather than increase, and for those with fluctuating work patterns, unpredictable behaviour, and some psychiatric disabilities, such flexible options may well be the only suitable and satisfying type of employment likely to allow their meaningful participation in the community.

To a degree, some existing work options may be able to offer such flexibility, and the special Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service units for people with psychiatric disabilities are a welcome move towards assisting a group of people with disabilities who have had limited access. Nonetheless, the Committee's consideration of new employment options (such as Competitive Employment Training and Placement—CETP—services and Supported Employment services) has led it to conclude that there is still room for these services to meet the needs of those more difficult to place. The Committee wishes to acknowledge that these options have provided varied work and employment opportunities, to people with mild, and moderate to severe disabilities, including intellectual disabilities. Nonetheless, the Committee also believes that these services have not been sufficiently evaluated to identify why some individuals benefit greatly from them, and others do not, or why access is easy for some and not for others.

Once again, the Committee is concerned that equity in access may not be available, and that the pressures placed on services to demonstrate success may have led to the 'easier' clients (including those with a supportive family) obtaining services more readily than the more difficult, or alienated clients. This was suggested by a number of witnesses, including those who operated such services and those who operated sheltered workshops. If this situation has occurred, it is imperative that the funding Department (Department of Health, Housing and Community Services) assess its own expectations and the pressures it may have placed on organisations, and determine if genuine equality of opportunity is being provided to people with disabilities.

A further major concern which the Committee has in respect of `new' employment services relates to the funding arrangements and the evaluation of services. One of the reasons for the setting up of this inquiry was to examine the ways in which new services differed from traditional sheltered workshops and how they provided opportunities to people who were considered to be less well served by established service types. In assessing evaluation and accountability processes, the Committee was concerned that inadequate funding appeared to have been provided for training and development of service providers, and that the Department itself had little information on the new services, with little accountability apparently being required. The Committee's consideration of sheltered workshops has identified a number of management problems which had become entrenched (as well as discriminatory practices which devalued clients). The Department was obviously well aware of poor management practices, limited accountability, and inability of workshops to meet the objectives of the Handicapped Persons' Assistance Act 1974 (replaced by the Disability Services Act 1986), and should have made every effort not to reproduce these problems in new services. The Committee believes that regular evaluation of, and reporting on, all services is required, that adequate funding be provided for training, that accountability processes be instituted, so that problems can be identified quickly and addressed with expert assistance. While in agreement with the general direction of new service types, the Committee believes that the goal of flexibility is best achieved through establishing firm parameters for services to work within.

In considering current and future employment options, the Committee undertook an evaluation of sheltered workshops, supplemented by visits to workshops in a number of States and discussions with service providers. The Committee has heard evidence from a number of organisations and individuals on the disadvantages of sheltered workshops and of the effect of certain attitudes and practices on people with disabilities. The Committee is unanimous in its support of service users having access to improved employment opportunities, better conditions, appropriate wages, dignity and respect. However, the Committee has also pointed out that funding limitations, poor management practices and lack of strict accountability procedures, have been among the causal factors of the unsatisfactory state of a number of workshops and of the failure to meet stated objectives. A number of parties have contributed to this situation, and must take responsibility for doing so. The Committee makes this point, not to contribute to the often bitter controversy about workshops, about the funding disparities between old and new services, about the expense of new services and the exclusion of many people from access to them, but to determine the reasons for poor performance.

In so doing, the Committee has considered the possible role of improved workshops in providing employment options, and is of the opinion that such workshops may have a role in providing training and employment opportunities in the future, particularly for people with severe disabilities and those people whose work patterns are variable and/or those whose skills may not increase or will decrease. This suggests that existing facilities could continue to have a role in providing employment options, although clearly adequate funding, staffing, training and expert managerial advice would be essential.

In reaching this conclusion, the Committee wishes to emphasise that it has recommended similar monitoring and evaluation processes for all service types currently offered by the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services, and that while it believes the problems of the workshops prior to transition have been demonstrated, the potential or real problem of new service types must also be clearly identified and solved if access is to be improved across the board.

Since the Committee began its inquiry, a number of changes have occurred in service provision, in the development of evaluation, in the workshop transition process, and transition time-frame, and many of these changes are supported by the Committee's findings. In particular, the Committee believes that the extension of the transition period and the establishment of the National Technical Assistance Unit have been major achievements, not least in that they are a recognition of the effect of past neglect, and of the capacity of services to provide real, meaningful options to people with disabilities. It is this, in conjunction with more thorough assessment of new services, and more effective labour-market training and work experience programs, which will provide a good foundation for the continued development of acceptable employment options.

The Committee has also considered related issues, such as skills-based wages, job-sharing, the costs associated with disability, the need for increased and appropriate support (such as transport, personal care, affordable aids and equipment and special leave). It has made a number of recommendations in these areas because of the importance which it places on increasing access to employment for people with disabilities.

Overall, the Committee believes that considerable changes have occurred over the past ten years. It also believes, however, that much still needs to be done to create and maintain a range of viable work options for people with disabilities, so that they have greater opportunity to participate more fully in society.

The Committee wishes to thank those individuals and organisations who made submissions, gave oral evidence to the Committee, and welcomed the Committee to their services. It also wishes to thank those Departments, especially the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services; the Department of Employment, Education and Training; the Department of Industrial Relations; and the Department of Social Security, which provided advice and assistance throughout the inquiry. The Committee also thanks past and present members of the Secretariat of the Committee who have worked on this inquiry.

Above all, the Committee would like to acknowledge the efforts of the individuals and organisations who have worked for so long to change public perception and understanding of people with disabilities and who have helped to move the debate from the individual to the broader community. As Disabled Peoples' International told us, 'Disability has too long been viewed as a problem of the individual and not the relationship for that individual and his/her environment.' Employment is, for most people, an important part of that environment.

Australian society must recognise that the community deprives itself of the talents and skills of hundreds of thousands of people as long as it fails to provide a range of appropriate employment options for Australians with disabilities, as well as denying those people the right to fuller participation in the community.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Committee on the Australian Security Intelligence Organization

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on the Australian Security Intelligence Organization, I present the Committee's report on the effect on ASIO of the operation of the access provisions of the Archives Act, together with the transcript of evidence and minutes of proceedings. The report is being tabled in both the House of Representatives and the Senate today. I seek leave to incorporate my tabling statement in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: MR PRESIDENT,

I have just tabled the Committee's report entitled `ASIO and the Archives Act', which is the first report to be presented to the Parliament by the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the Australian Security Intelligence Organization. The report addresses the question referred to the Committee of how the activities of ASIO are affected by the operation of the Archives Act 1983.

PARA.TAB: The Archives Act first came into operation in 1983 and provides a right of public access to records of the Commonwealth that are more than 30 years old: the 30-year rule. This is subject to the right of the government to withhold records on defence and security and a number of other grounds. Decisions to withhold material are appealable to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The government can reinforce its claim for exemption by applying a `Conclusive Certificate' to the record.

The 30-year rule applies and has applied to ASIO and the other intelligence agencies of the Commonwealth from the proclamation of the Archives Act in 1983. ASIO is exempted from the general requirement of the Archives Act relating to the transfer of records to the Archives and retains full control over its records, only releasing material through the archives in response to specific requests.
In the seven years of the operation of the Act more than 1,600 ASIO files have been wholly or partially released for public access under the provisions of the Act.

ASIO and the other agencies in the intelligence communities have consistently opposed the application of the 30-year rule to their records. They were supported in this position by the Royal Commissioner, Mr Justice Hope, in 1985, who recommended in his Report into Australia's Intelligence Security Agencies (RCAISA) that ASIO's operational files be excluded from the cover of the Archives Act and released only at the discretion of the Director-General of Security.

The Government did not accept the RCASIA recommendation and in tabling the RCASIA report in May 1985, the then Prime Minister, the Hon. R J L Hawke, AC, MP, stated the view of the Government that the provisions of the Archives Act were already adequate to protect the legitimate concerns of the intelligence community, which should continue to be subject to the 30-year rule.

There has continued to be a difference of opinion between the intelligence community and the government on this matter of release of records. In each of its annual reports since 1984 ASIO has continued to seek a review of the decision that it should be bound by the 30 year rule. It was in these circumstances that the Committee was asked to undertake the present review which has been effectively under way since May 1990.
It should be noted that this Report is not a general review of the operation of the Archives Act.

ASIO submitted that the 30-year rule was too short and that its records and those of the other Intelligence Agencies should be embargoed for 50 years. It submitted that a decision to withhold a record from release on security grounds should not be reviewable on appeal to the AAT.

While the Committee shares the concern of ASIO about certain classes of records, it does not accept the argument that the entire ASIO archive should be closed for 50 years. The Committee's general finding is that ASIO records should continue to be subject to the access provisions of the Archives Act and the open access period in respect of ASIO records should continue to be 30 years from the creation of the record.

The first of ASIO's specific concerns relates to intelligence information supplied by Australia's defence and intelligence partners. The Committee was told and accepts that these allies supply or exchange intelligence information which is of crucial importance to Australia's defence and security and that they might terminate or reduce the level and quality of their cooperation unless completely satisfied with the level of protection provided in Australia. The Committee was told that Australia's comparatively liberal document access was a cause of concern to allies and could result in a reduction or down-grading of cooperation.

To ensure the continued flow of high quality intelligence material the Committee recommends that it should be embargoed as long as it remains under embargo in the nation supplying it (Recommendation 1). It reinforces Recommendation 1 by proposing that once the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security (IGIS) has certified the foreign derived provenance of a record there should be no further appeal to the AAT from a decision not to release it (Recommendation 2).

Another specific area of concern is the need to protect agents sources, targets and methods of operation of the Organization. It is difficult to see how an intelligence agency can function if it were not able to give guaranteed anonymity to its operatives. The Committee recommends that the identity of sources, agents and operatives should be guaranteed in guidelines for a period of 30 years from the persons death.

However, the Committee did not accept an argument of ASIO that it should be able to claim an exemption on behalf of individuals mentioned in ASIO records, on broad grounds of privacy, unrelated to security. The Committee was satisfied that privacy rights of individuals were adequately protected under the general provisions of the Archives Act as administered by Australian Archives.

Nor did the Committee accept the submission of ASIO that the right of appeal to the AAT from a refusal to release ASIO records should be abolished. ASIO had proposed that an appeal to the IGIS should be substituted.

The Committee makes three Recommendations regarding the appeal process. The Archives Act provides a two-tiered system of review. A person refused access can, first, apply for an internal reconsideration. This is currently determined by the Director-General of Archives on the advice of ASIO. If still dissatisfied the applicant can appeal to the AAT.

The Committee recommends that the Director-General of Security, not the Director-General of Archives, should determine applications for internal review which involve national security records. We have concluded that there should be a further right of appeal from the Director-General of Security through the IGIS to the Attorney-General. An appeal to the AAT should lie from the decision of the Attorney-General.

For their part the clients of the Archives wishing to access ASIO records have expressed deep frustration both as to the failure of ASIO to comply with requests for access within the statutory period of 90 days and to a perceived failure of the Organization to be cooperative in its dealing with its client group.

This evidence was strongly in favour of ASIO remaining subject to the 30-year rule and highly critical of the manner in which ASIO has responded to its legal obligation to provide access to its records. ASIO has been compared unfavourably with other Commonwealth agencies with whom these scholars deal for access to defence and security records. A problem here is that there is no identifiable person at ASIO with whom scholars can meet to negotiate complicated requests for information. Other Commonwealth agencies such as the departments of Defence and Foreign Affairs and Trade employ a designated official qualified to negotiate for the department and assist clients to formulate their requests.

ASIO does not provide scholars with finding aids and indices as these departments do, with the result that scholars are forced to trawl by making omnibus requests in the hope of turning up the information that they want.

ASIO releases records only after they have undergone a painstaking and labour intensive scrutiny by "clearers" who are Senior Intelligence Officers on a routine posting. The records released as a result of this process frequently disappoint the expectations of the clients who complain that they have been culled to such an extent that the only material released is documents already in the public domain.

The Committee has, however, been satisfied that the process of clearing is justified on grounds of national security. The AAT in its decisions has endorsed the internal processes applied by ASIO and decisions made by ASIO to withhold material on national security grounds. It is unlikely, therefore that, as result of this report applicants will receive more material than they are getting now.

Despite these constraints the Committee believes that there is room for improvement in the way ASIO handles access requests. First, the Government must appropriate sufficient resources to enable ASIO to discharge its statutory obligations. There is a need for a change in ethos on the part of ASIO to a more cooperative approach. We recommend that an archival unit within ASIO be established to consult and negotiate with researchers, particularly those with large requests. Less complicated requests should be fast-tracked. The unit needed to be accessible to the public and this means that it needs to be headed by a person who can be known to the public.
This will require a change to the ASIO Act which currently requires the anonymity of all ASIO personnel other than the Director-General of Security.

The unit should also develop indices and finding aids that can be made available to the public without infringing national security and can also devote some resources to preparing records, in advance, for release as they fall into the open access period.

Finally, Mr President, there have been expressions of concern that individuals have no right of access to records of ASIO to ensure that information about them on ASIO files is accurate. In certain cases, the Freedom of Information Act and the Privacy Act provide such rights in relation to the current records, but not to ASIO as that legislation does not apply to the intelligence agencies. Such agencies routinely refuse to confirm or deny whether they have individuals under surveillance or hold records on them.

The Committee acknowledges that this is the only possible stance for an intelligence agency to adopt. However, in Recommendation 14 we suggest a means whereby a person may bring information to the attention of the IGIS which he would then be required to bring to the attention of any intelligence agency to whom it might be relevant.

Mr President, the Committee believes the adoption of these proposals will ensure that the security interests of the Commonwealth continue to receive proper protection, at the same time ensuring that important national records are preserved for posterity, while providing at the same time as wide a right of public access to those records commensurate with the requirements of national security.

Finally, Mr President, I would like to place on record my thanks to my colleagues on the Committee and to those who contributed to the inquiry for the time and effort they have put in. I am particularly pleased that we have been able to achieve a unanimous Report. I would also like to thank the staff who have supported us during the inquiry: Anne Hazelton and Donald Nairn as Secretaries, ably supported by Pat Sherman.
I commend the Report to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: 27 March 1992

Chairman

Sydney South NSW 2001
Dear Mr Hoare

I refer to AOTC's response of 23 March 1992 to the recommendations of the 12 December 1991 interim report, on telephone services, of the Senate Select Committee on Community Services Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Telecommunications Technologies.

AOTC'S RESPONSE TO RECOMMENDATIONS CONTAINED IN THE INTERIM REPORT OF THE SENATE SELECT COMMITTEE ON COMMUNITY STANDARDS RELEVANT TO THE SUPPLY OF SERVICES UTILISING TELECOMMUNICATIONS TECHNOLOGIES
AOTC appreciates the work of the Committee to this stage and is generally supportive of the recommendations contained in the Interim Report relating to 0055 services.

Before providing specific responses to the Recommendations in the Report, we would like to take the opportunity to comment on the following matters raised in the Committee's Report and the Chairperson's tabling statement in Parliament:
.At paragraph 4.14 of the report, the Committee "commends the Minister for his intervention and condemns Telecom for its obvious lack of concern for principles of accountability to Parliament".

Although the Minister's letter to Telecom of 17 September 1991 regarding "adult" services was not a formal direction, Telecom took positive steps to implement the Minister's wishes. Until we are in a position to implement the Committee's recommendations concerning new standards, AOTC has had no alternative but to follow the procedures developed in the new Codes of Practice.

Telecom's interpretation of the Minister's letter was that "adult" messages are those which did not conform to the new code of Practice and these should be modified, withdrawn or migrated to the 0051 service.
AOTC, therefore, does not understand the Committee's conclusion that Telecom's actions showed a "lack of concern for principles of accountability to Parliament".
.In the tabling statement, the Chairperson states that "the Committee has rejected Telecom's approach to the problem (control of message content) essentially because it is clearly not working".

The Codes of Practice formulated by the Telephone Information Service Standards Committee (TISSC) were introduced on 1 October 1991. AOTC's view is that any new mechanism for control of message content and advertising needs time to indicate positive results. It is of note that action taken by Telecom since October as well as action initiated by Service Providers has resulted in a large reduction in the number of advertisements for adult services in the media. Also, 1075 public complaints (independent of Telecom actions) have been handled by the Telephone Information Services Arbitrator to the end of January 1992.

.A further point in the tabling statement is critical of Telecom "for its failure to fully respond to the Committee's operations and for having proceeded with certain areas of policy measures, which clearly fall within the Committee's terms of reference, while the Committee's inquiry has still been in progress".

AOTC is disappointed at this criticism as Telecom's intentions in regard to the Codes of Practice for 0055 and 0051 were made clear in our original submission and in subsequent discussions, for example, Hansard pages 61 and 62.

In addition, at the last hearing on 7 November 1991, Telecom put the view, and understood that the Chairperson agreed with it, that our actions had not been pre-emptive. This was on the basis that revised contracts incorporating the new Codes of Practice had not been signed. However, Service Providers have formally agreed to abide by the Codes of Practice.

AOTC's comments on the recommendations are set out below. We reserve the right to reconsider our views, however, in the light of the Committee's final report and of any further debate on these matters by the Senate as a whole.
Recommendation 1: That Telecom adopt as the code of conduct for its message standard for the 0055 open access service the following:

PARA.TAB: (a)The Service Provider will not provide knowingly or negligently on any 0055 number allocated to it, information which in any way may be interpreted as indecent, obscene, offensive or sexually titillating or denoting sexual suggestion or sexual fantasy; and

(b)The Service Provider will not provide knowingly or negligently on any 0055 number allocated to it, messages whether described as medical or otherwise which contain material that a reasonable parent would not wish his or her child to hear without parental guidance.

SPEECH.PARA: AOTC can accept in principle this recommendation which contains the wording from the Message Standards section of the previous 0055 Operational Requirements. However, there is a concern that the sweeping nature of the provision, and, in particular, the words "in any way" in part (a) would set a standard of such a low threshold that any person's judgement would be determinative. It will be recalled that it was this broad sweep which in many instances made this requirement unrealistic for Telecom to enforce when it was part of the earlier standards. AOTC suggests that any words "in any way" should be deleted.

AOTC's experience has been that there is a strong community demand for medical messages. On our reading, the Committee's recommendation leaves it open for suitably authorised and appropriately structured medical messages to continue to be available on the 0055 service. However a message that would otherwise be acceptable under part (a) may fail under the "reasonable parent" test in part (b) of the recommendation.

AOTC suggests that the Committee should give further consideration to the genuine community need for such messages on the one hand and the concern of parents relating to access by children on the other.

Whilst not specifically covered in this recommendation, it is noted from the tabling statement in Parliament on 12 December 1991 that the Committee proposes adoption of advertising and other standards from Telecom's previous Operational Requirements.
If the Committee's view is that advertising and other standards should parallel the message content standards, an explicit reference should be included in the recommendation to avoid any confusion.

Recommendation 2: That Telecom ensure that all services currently provided on 0055 which are in breach of the message standard as listed in Recommendation 1 are either migrated immediately to the 0051 closed user access service or are withdrawn outright.

AOTC agrees in principle with this recommendation. Obviously if a message does not comply with the standards in Recommendation No. 1 once they are incorporated into contracts with Service Providers, it will not continue to be connected to 0055.
There are three matters requiring attention in implementation of this recommendation:

PARA.TAB: 1.The new standards will need to be incorporated in revised contracts between Service Providers and Telecom (see Recommendation No. 4)
2.A mechanism is to be established for messages to be judged as complying with the standards (see Recommendation No. 5)
3.The options for Service Providers should include withdrawal of a message and re-connection following suitable modification to a message.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation 3: That Telecom adopt as the code of conduct for its message standard for the 0051 closed user access service the following:

The Service Provider will not provide knowingly or negligently on any 0051 number allocated to it, information which in any way may be interpreted as equivalent to the R or X film/video classification.
AOTC accepts this recommendation in principle and, consistent with our response to Recommendation No. 1(a), suggests that the words "in any way" be deleted.
The recommendation would therefore read ". . . . . . . . . information which may be interpreted as equivalent. . . . . . . . . ".
The linking of audio and visual classifications could cause difficulties in interpretation but no doubt the work could be undertaken on a good faith basis by a qualified agency.
Recommendation 4: That Telecom discontinue its contractual agreements with Service Providers and offer new contractual agreements which observe the recommended code of conduct.

AOTC agrees to this recommendation and will endeavour to have new contracts in place at an early date. To this end, Telecom has been discussing with the Office of Film and Literature Classification (OFLC) the proposed role for the OFLC and new standards for message content. The OFLC is preparing draft standards, based on the Committee's recommendations and discussions, to replace the relevant parts of the current Codes of Practice.

AOTC has also been discussing the question of new contracts with Service Providers, the Telephone Information Services Standards Committee (TISSC) and the Telephone Information Service Arbitrator (TISA). In particular the contracts will need to cover consumer protection issues which are not within the province of the OFLC.
It might be noted that Service Providers have not agreed to adopt the Committee's recommended standards and have challenged AOTC's legal right to vary the contracts.
Recommendation 5: That Telecom enter into a contract with the Office of Film and Literature Classification for it to act as the monitoring and enforcement body for the code of conduct.

This recommendation is acceptable in principle to AOTC and the OFLC has been contacted (see response to Recommendation No. 4). The cost of the new arrangements will be a factor in the contract negotiations with the OFLC.

AOTC's view is that there will still be significant roles for TISSC and TISA in areas other than message content and advertising standards, for example, consumer protection issues (see also response to Recommendation No. 4).
Recommendation 6: That Telecom undertake to introduce an immediate program of random monitoring to ensure contractual compliance of message content on both 0055 and 0051 with the code of conduct.

AOTC agrees in principle with this recommendation and will make continuing arrangements for random monitoring of 0055 services. This must be co-ordinated with the similar OFLC activities requested by the Committee.
Recommendation 7: That the code of conduct provide that any message content breach will lead to service disconnection on the first occasion and contract cancellation on any subsequent occasion.

AOTC agrees that there need to be appropriate sanctions for breaches of standards. We also agree that discontinuation of a message may well be appropriate in certain circumstances. However, AOTC cannot agree with the recommendation as worded, for the following reasons:

PARA.TAB: (a)Cancellation of a Service Provider's total contract for a subsequent breach is considered to be too general a prescription and could be construed as unfair and unreasonable because of the automatic application proposed.

(b)Most Service Providers are involved in a wide range of messages. Cancellation of the entire contract for two offending messages would be a harsh penalty. Cancellation of a contract would penalise users of other messages provided by the same Service Provider.

(c)Breaches of the code of conduct can range from relatively harmless to very serious and the proposed penalty in the recommendation does not adequately reflect the range of breaches. This is another aspect of the unfairness and unreasonableness of the recommendation.
(d)Situations arise where the breach is not the fault of the Service Provider. Penalties should have regard to fault if they are to facilitate appropriate conduct.

SPEECH.PARA: Taking the above into account, AOTC would prefer the recommendation to be framed to provide that contracts with Service Providers should require immediate discontinuation of a message when it is determined to be in breach of the standards in Recommendation No. 1. There should be a range of penalties for various types of breaches as is currently described in the Codes of Practice and, in addition, there should be provision for contract cancellation for flagrant, significant or continuing breaches of the message content standards.

Recommendation 8: That the Service Providers be required to provide basic consumer information on the duration and cost of each message at the beginning of each recorded message; the cost of doing this to be borne by the Service Provider.
AOTC agrees in principle with this recommendation but, as noted by the Committee in paragraph 4.77 of its Interim Report, implementation is not practicable in the short term.

Major development work would be necessary to effect changes to current billing arrangements. The need to exempt 0055 calls which record a vote in polls or enter miscellaneous competitions adds to the complexity of the problem. Obviously, this recommendation will require a detailed technical investigation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly about a matter of considerable importance to the Senate because on one view it could constitute an abuse of the process of Senate committee hearings. It concerns statements made by the Australian Workers Union that it has only recently become aware of commercial links between certain farming organisations and certain insurance companies.

PARA.TAB: In March this year, in a submission to the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation, the Australian Workers Union claimed that until recently it had been unaware of commercial links between employer associations and insurance companies. Its concerns particularly relate to the circumstances in which the pastoral award provides for two insurance companies to be the sponsors of superannuation funds, the fact that those insurance companies conduct a wide range of insurance business and that commissions paid by those companies to agents and others are the subject of commercial links with certain farming organisations. It is not suggested by anyone, as I understand it, that there are any commissions payable on the sale of superannuation business. Nor is it suggested by the AWU that there is anything improper in these arrangements.

The AWU has said to the Senate Committee that it was simply not aware of these commercial links. In a letter dated 19 March, the Secretary of the union, Michael Forshaw, wrote to the Managing Director of the Australian Eagle Insurance Company Ltd, complaining in very strong terms about some comments in a letter in the Sydney Morning Herald written by the Managing Director, Mr Lester.
The General Secretary of the AWU said that information regarding payments to insurance companies and the commercial relationship with these bodies:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . was never revealed to the Industrial Relations Commission at the time the Pastoral Industry Superannuation Award was first made. It was certainly never made known to the AWU even though we are a party to the Industrial Award which provides for superannuation contributions to be paid into the fund managed by your company. Rather this information only came to our knowledge some time after the Award was made. In my view, this was relevant and material information that should have been disclosed at the time.

These outbursts of indignation about total ignorance relating to commercial links found their way into the Sydney Morning Herald and subsequently were the subject of discussion on the Country Hour on Radio National. As one would imagine, that program achieves quite wide currency in the farming community. Therefore, Radio National became a vehicle for the retailing of these concerns. Indeed, the presenter commenced the program by pointing out that the union, in giving evidence to the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation, had said:
. . . the National Farmers Federation and some state farmer organisations failed to reveal commercial links with insurance funds handling superannuation payments.

Senator Nick Sherry, the Chairman of the Select Committee, was also interviewed on the program. I say in passing that Senator Sherry is doing an excellent job as Chairman of that Committee, but unfortunately he, too, appears to have been misled on the basis of this information. It had been argued that the commercial relationship should have been disclosed and he expressed some concerns about this. He said:

The allegation made to us was that there is a commercial relationship . . . and that should have been disclosed at the time the superannuation fund was set up. . . I think it's an important issue that superannuation funds, if it is claimed that they're independent, are in fact totally independent and there is no commercial relationship.
The question of independence relates purely to the question of the status of the trustees of the funds and that matter has been made clear from the outset.

PARA.TAB: The National Farmers Federation has engaged in heated disputation with the AWU about whether there should be worker representatives on the boards of trustees. The NFF's position is that it is much more appropriate to have people with commercial expertise, but as a fall back position they would contemplate employer and employee representatives on the board. But it does not believe that it is appropriate to have union representatives on the board because the level of unionisation in the pastoral industry is very low. I will come in a moment to the consequences of even having superannuation provisions apply in the pastoral industry.

The fact is that on the basis of those sorts of allegations, clearly an attempt is being made by the Australian Workers Union to suggest that somehow these commercial links have only recently surfaced and that that is a matter of great concern. It is significant that at present Commissioner Merriman has reserved his decision on a review he has conducted about superannuation arrangements in the pastoral industry. That decision is expected to be handed down shortly.

This raises concern that the AWU has sought to raise these allegations at this time under parliamentary privilege through the Senate Committee and that these allegations have found their way into the Sydney Morning Herald and on Radio National. The facts reveal that this is simply not the case. I wish to take the Senate to the transcript of evidence relating to the original application when the matter was before the Industrial Relations Commission and the provisions of the pastoral award were being determined.

Far from these commercial links not having been made known to the Commission, I would point out that Mr Costello, who appeared for the employer respondents, indicated at the outset that he proposed to call evidence in relation to the Australian farm superannuation fund, a fund sponsored inter alia by the Victorian Farmers Federation in conjunction with Australian Eagle. Evidence was given by a Mr Towers, a principal witness. When asked what was the Victorian farmers insurance agency, Mr Towers's evidence was that it was:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a linkup between Australian Eagle and the Victorian Farmers Federation which provides general insurance assistance to Victorian farmers. So it is a network throughout the State'.
Most importantly, he was asked what source of money the agency derived to pay its people. The answer was:
They would be on the commission they had received for the policies they had sold'.

In other words, Mr Towers was making it perfectly plain that commissions were payable on general insurance and that that was a matter that was on the table from the outset. It is therefore extraordinary not only that the AWU should pretend that somehow it was never aware of these commercial links, but also that it should seek to raise the matter at this time. I think one is entitled to draw the conclusion that this is a fairly grubby attempt to try to influence the Industrial Relations Commission at the eleventh hour, after all the evidence is in but while the umpire is still presumably making up his mind.

PARA.TAB: We know that the Government and the ACTU have no respect at all for the notion of an independent IRC. We have only to look at the howls of outrage which followed the 1991 national wage case when the Commission had the temerity to suggest that award superannuation was simply not working. Since that time the Commission has been subjected to unprecedented and outrageous bully boy tactics by the likes of Cabinet Ministers Cook and Kelty—a campaign of abuse, intimidation and vilification that would make Mike Tyson blush and which was clearly designed to influence the IRC or, failing that, to cut it off at the knees. That is why Mr Kelty is so determined that it should not even retain the nexus of pay with Federal Court judges.

The fact remains that these allegations by the AWU are simply not true. I think the real explanation is this: Mr Forshaw, who was the General Secretary at the time and who was obviously aware of the commercial links, simply did not do his homework. In other words, he did not research the matter. He could easily have looked at the annual reports of the Victorian Farmers Federation and other State organisations, discovered the true nature and extent of those commercial links, the amounts of moneys that were being paid by way of commission, and then, if necessary, have made a further submission to the IRC or, indeed, have amplified concerns expressed at the time. But he did not do any of that. In other words, he was too lazy. He simply proceeded on the basis of the evidence and then discovered matters later on of which he was clearly capable of having knowledge earlier. Then to disguise his own incompetence and ineptitude he has resorted to this sort of blustering tactic, presumably to persuade his own membership that this is a matter of current concern when in fact, if it was ever a matter of concern, it was a matter that should have been known to him and should have been raised at the time.

I think in the circumstances it is incumbent on Mr Forshaw to make a full and frank explanation, which I would have thought would involve an apology for attempting to mislead the Senate Committee, and certainly to withdraw any inference that this is designed to influence the Commission in its deliberations. I would be very interested to hear Mr Forshaw's explanation for his going over the top in the way that he did. I can understand that because he did not do his homework he might not have been aware of the full nature and extent of these commercial arrangements, but the fact remains that they were fully disclosed at the time. He could have known more about them if he had chosen to inquire further, but he simply did not. That is in no way a sufficient justification for taking up the time of the Senate Committee in the way that he has and attempting to mislead the Senate Committee and others by suggesting that he was not aware of these commercial links.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am appalled that the importance of the ministerial statement on the final report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody has been marginalised by the timetabling of the Senate program and the complete disregard of that program by speakers from the Opposition pursuing their own agendas. It would be a travesty of justice both to the families of all those who have died in custody either under the consideration of the Royal Commission or outside it and to all the hours of bureaucratic effort put into addressing it if it were to be marginalised by the low priority so far allocated to it in this Senate.

I conclude with an urgent plea to all honourable senators. I request that any honourable senator who has not actually read one of the 99 individual case studies of the deaths reported by the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody should choose one from within their own State.
