—I want to make a few remarks about what I think is a very sad day for Australia when we see the Government taking action to ban the right to trade in products that are legal. For me, the right to trade in products that are legal includes the right to advertise, the right to sponsor and the right to promote that legal product. I refer to the Government's decision to ban sponsorship of sporting events and, indeed, cultural events and any other events concerning the tobacco industry and smoking.

PARA.TAB: I say right at the outset that I gave up smoking about 16 years ago and I did it for reasons that made sense to me. However, I will defend the right of anyone who wishes to smoke to do so and I will defend the right of the companies to promote their products through the ordinary outlets that are available, be they be billboards, sponsorship, television, or radio. With the so-called death of socialism, we find in our community a small but growing band of people who want to impose their values on everybody else—the regulators; the people who want to tell you what is good for you and what is not good for you, what you may have what you may not have, when you may have it and when you may not have it. They may think they have had a win today with the banning of the sponsorship of tobacco products. What will be next, the alcohol industry? Then they will move on to the confectionery industry and the manufacturers of armchairs. Perhaps they will move on to the day-to-day right that we have to choose between a wool product and a synthetic product. The world is full of people who want to tell us how we ought to spend our dollars, how we ought to make judgments.

It is most important that we determine that we have civil liberties in our country, and that we have the right to deal with products that are legal. Why do those people who want to see tobacco products banned not have the courage to come out and fight that issue? A survey of the newspapers the other day showed that 70 per cent of ordinary Australian citizens believe that companies ought to have the right to sponsor sporting events, cultural events or any other activity that they wish to sponsor. Seventy per cent of Australian opinion is just to be knocked out by the people who are determined to regulate the way in which everybody lives.

It is an important issue. As I have already said, I chose for myself what I wanted to do with regard to cigarettes, and it is the right of every other Australian to make his or her own judgment. And it is the right of those people who are opposed or who think that there is an adverse effect on health to raise their own money and, if they want to do so, to put a program to air advocating that people give it up. Competition of ideas in the media is what I am talking about.

I suppose I should not be surprised that this is a Government that wants to ban things. After all, we have been denied the right of freedom of speech with regard to political advertising. Such advertising has been banned for the most cynical of reasons. So why should I be surprised that the Government would go ahead and ban the rights of people to deal with products that are legal.It is indeed a sad day for Australia because it could be said that it is the thin edge of the wedge; it will be used as a precedent.

There has been a concerted campaign to make tobacco and alcohol somehow synonymous with the illegal and illicit drugs that kill or ruin the lives of young people. There has been a concerted campaign to try to say that tobacco and alcohol are just as bad as heroin or cocaine or marijuana or amphetamines. Well, it is wrong. Our society has made a judgment. We have adjudged that alcohol and tobacco are legal products within our community and that the others are not. We have adjudged that we can find ways of dealing with those products in our society which allow a legal product to be dealt with in the way I have earlier described in terms of advertising and sales. But here we have the thin edge of the wedge, which is a threat to every other manufacturer, seller, retailer of products which some group will determine are really not in the best interests of citizens.

In a democracy I believe that individuals are entitled to make up their own minds. I do not wear the argument that some people are better at making up other people's minds for them. I do not want a judgment about whose IQ is high enough to make a judgment about his or her own life. My colleague Senator Baume was just talking about disabled sportsmen who have made a judgment for themselves that they will not be disbarred from taking part in any aspect of life they choose. Ordinarily, one might say that because of their impairment they are unable to participate in competitive sport. Well, they have decided for themselves that their own will will entitle them to do it, and more courage to them.

I do not need a group of do-gooders, a group of thought police or a group of regulators to tell the Australian people when they may exercise their democratic rights and when they may not. The day that those people who want to see tobacco products banned have the courage to come out and fight on their true intention, then that is the day we can debate that issue. But simply to say that by regulation we will try to force them out of business is a very dangerous precedent to set indeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw attention to an answer that was given to me in Question Time by the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook. In doing so I want to highlight a tactic that is being adopted by a number of Government Ministers—and Senator Lewis highlighted this today—who begin answers to questions by saying or inferring that one has the question wrong.

PARA.TAB: This tactic will get the Government into all sorts of trouble because we will come back—in particular, I will come back—and point out where the Government is wrong. Senator Cook, in his comments today, was wrong, not only in the substance of what he said—he has misled the Senate, as I contended in my question today—but also in his assertion that I have got it wrong. I want to explain why he is wrong. He cast aspersions on the accuracy of my question. My question yesterday was very carefully worded. The words were ` to force contractors to operate within the award system'. I underline that word `force'. I turn to the press release the Minister put out yesterday. I intend to explain why I assert that the word `force' is correct. I will quote two paragraphs of that press release which relate to this matter and to the Minister's emphatic answer,` No' to my question yesterday. His press release states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Industrial Relations Commission will have regard to relevant customs and practice in a dispute over independent contractors and ensure that their use is not harsh or unfair.

He says `dispute'. This will affect every contractor in this country, because all anybody has to do where contractors are operating is to bring on a dispute. That can be brought on in a number of ways: by withdrawing labour and going on strike, or by lodging an application with the Industrial Relations Commission stating that there is a particular problem. That could be done to any contractor in any situation in any workplace in Australia. The Minister then goes on to say:
The Commission can also determine whether the total remuneration of contractors will be less than that of employees and whether there is any intention to avoid obligations under awards.

For Senator Cook yesterday, and also again today, to state that this would not have an impact on all contractors is truly false. It is false for the very reason I gave regarding the last paragraph I quoted, in that a dispute can be brought on. These contractors have made their own arrangements with their employees, whether they be part of a contract team, or whether the contractor is contracted out to an owner or employer to carry out certain tasks in a certain area, which for example could be the building industry. The cottage building industry has expressed the most concern.

PARA.TAB: It is blatantly wrong and totally false to suggest that the implications of this legislation as presented in this press release will not affect contractors in the building industry or, for that matter, contractors in any other industry. Once a dispute is brought before the Australian Industrial Relations Commission pressure will be put on those contractors to comply in terms of the various existing awards.

The next thing I want to refer to regarding the answer that was given to me today is the use of term, `sham contractors'. The use of the term, `sham contractors' is aimed absolutely and blatantly at none other than Troubleshooters—except that the Minister has not said Troubleshooters. It is aimed at the concept that Troubleshooters have introduced in recent years into the Australian contract system. I particularly want to refer to the last part of Senator Cook's answer to me today, where he said:

But in other areas, customs and practices may well be different. On a multi-storey construction site in the middle of the central business district of a capital city, custom and practice would be award coverage, and, should people wish then to try and break that down by introducing sham contracts, the Commission would have regard to that award area of award coverage and award against the so-called independent contractors.

I want to point out Troubleshooters' contract arrangements. The first area in which it worked—and worked very successfully, I might add—was in the building construction industry. This proposed legislation is targeted directly at it, and it is targeted against this legal background: the BWIU took action in the Federal Court before Justice Woodward in early 1989. The case that it put to Justice Woodward was that the activities of Troubleshooters should be ruled out by the Federal Court. In fact, Justice Woodward, when he had heard all the evidence and information, upheld the position of Troubleshooters. In summing up, in his judgment he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Individuals or groups have the right to choose whether they wish to work as a contractor or contractors, combined, or for a contractor.

The union then appealed the decision to the Full Bench of the Federal Court. The Federal Court upheld the decision of Justice Woodward. The BWIU then sought leave to appeal to the High Court in regard to the decisions of both Justice Woodward of the Federal Court and the Full Bench of the Federal Court. The High Court looked at the evidence in the case and rejected the application to appeal to the High Court.

PARA.TAB: It has been upheld by both the Federal Court and the High Court of Australia, the highest court in the land, that Troubleshooters, the contractors referred to in this press release—and I will refer to further evidence of that in a moment or two—is operating an activity which is within the law of this country. They have upheld not only the operations of Troubleshooters, but also the rights of individuals—something that Senator Bishop was talking about a moment ago—to determine whether they want to work as a contractor, whether they want to work as a group in forming a contract arrangement, or whether they want to work for a contractor.

I would like to fill in some of the background to this decision that has been made by the Minister in giving notice of his intention to introduce this legislation which will, in effect, as I said, force contractors in this country to have no other option but to be pressured, regarding the arrangements they make, into taking another aspect into account in terms of award coverage. Contractors should have the right to determine how they want to take on a particular task, the period of time involved and the conditions under which that particular task will be carried out. I want to highlight first a letter from the Building Workers Industrial Union of Australia to Mr Bill Kelty, Secretary of the ACTU. It is signed by Tom McDonald, National Secretary. I will read the first four paragraphs of this letter:
The consequences of the agreement between the BLF and Troubleshooters is an important matter for the trade union movement and trade unionists.
The agreement represents the first major breakthrough for the New Right in its efforts to take the Australian work force out of the award and arbitration system and into the quagmire of contracting.
This development represents a serious threat to the future of the trade union movement because, as history shows, contracting leads to a breakdown of union organisation and membership.

BWIU have been in a long running battle with Troubleshooters and has incurred legal costs to the order of $200,000 and is currently facing legal action by Troubleshooters for damages against the union.

SPEECH.PARA: I read that particularly to highlight two things. One is that this decision by the Minister results from a dispute between the BWIU and the Builders Labourers Federation. We have had some discussion in this chamber in recent times in terms of the position of mega-unions. I will no go into that today. It also highlights the direct move by the BWIU to the Secretary of the ACTU to override, by whatever means available, the decision of Justice Woodward, as I said, which was upheld by, first, the Full Bench of the Federal Court and, second, the High Court—that fundamental decision or principle that individuals have the right to choose.

PARA.TAB: It is rather interesting that four hours after my question to the Minister yesterday, when we got an emphatic `no', a press release was put out which is quite different from the answer that was given to me yesterday.

I turn to the next piece of information. On 14 February 1992 we had another letter—I have it here—from the Building Workers Industrial Union of Australia to its membership. I am not going to read the whole letter, only a paragraph of it. It says—and note the date, 14 February 1992; yesterday was 1 April 1992:

SPEECH.PARA: We have also been vindicated by the fact that the Federal Government has announced its intention to pass legislation making the Troubleshooters' type of arrangements illegal by changing the Federal Industrial Relations Act.

This highlights the fact that the BWIU was informed at least before 14 February 1992 of the position, yet yesterday, in answer to a question of mine in this chamber, the Minister could not tell us what the Government's intentions were. He answered emphatically, `No', yet four hours later he could put out a press release highlighting the situation. That proves quite conclusively that the Minister has more regard for his position, which in the past has been with the BWIU, than he has for this Senate chamber.

PARA.TAB: I would like to make some general comments on workplace reform. The Minister referred today to those people in the cottage industries. He implied that what he called `genuine contractors'—he did not use these words but that is what he meant—would not have their arrangements in terms of housing construction, which have served this nation well for a long time, put in jeopardy. That is not correct. The legislation will increase disputation regarding the building of homes and units, et cetera, and will create unnecessary disruption on those sites.

But it goes further than that. What the legislation is also saying is that Australian industrial relations have to stand still. He says in his answer that if it has been the practice in the past—and I refer to construction sites—we are going to have to stay with the old practices of the past; we cannot progress into the twenty-first century. As we move into the twenty-first century we could well see—and I believe that we will—totally different arrangements to those that have prevailed in the past on building sites and on any other manufacturing sites in this country. It is irresponsible of the Minister to stop progress in terms of modernising our contracting practice and keeping pace with the best international practice.

In Thailand, for example, where I was recently, they would not put up with this nonsense. They work a contract system and they work around the clock under the arrangements they have in their contract system. America also has a contract system. I say to Government senators and to the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook: why should Australia not adopt the best contracting practices which exist in other countries? I reiterate my claim in my question today: Senator Cook in his answer yesterday to this Senate misled the Senate.

The practice of stating at the beginning of the answer to a question that it is either wrong or it is weird has been followed a couple of times this week, and it is very poor. I must say to the Minister at the table, Senator Tate, that I have not yet heard him adopt that practice in this chamber, and I hope that he does not do so. But I would ask him to convey to his colleagues that it is a not a desirable practice in this chamber.

My claim that we were misled by the Minister is borne out by the facts. I refer to an article published in the Australian Financial Review last week by Paddy McGuinness. He said words to the effect that Senator Cook's official title in this place was Minister for Industrial Relations, but in the real world it was the Minister for the Prime Minister and Bill Kelty. I would like to add, in the light of the material that I have raised here in this place today, that the title be extended to Minister for the BWIU.

Senator Cook is determined to wipe out what has been a very successful innovation in terms of contracting that has been introduced by troubleshooters in the construction industry and other industries in this country. I would warn—notify all contractors that if this legislation goes through in the context in which it has been put out in the press release by the Minister they will all be affected because they will become part of the dispute process in this country. Once that happens, they will be subject to scrutiny by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to say a few words about a recent visit to Jordan undertaken by myself and my husband during the parliamentary recess.

PARA.TAB: The visit was important on a number of counts, not the least because it enabled me, as a newlywed, to spend some time with my husband, a man whom I had barely seen since my appointment to this place late last year.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have to make these sacrifices!

—One certainly does, Senator Boswell, as I have realised very quickly. From a national perspective, once I arrived in Jordan I realised—and was told in fact—that I was the first member of the Federal Parliament to visit Jordan since the Gulf war. From that point of view the Jordanian Government certainly regarded my humble presence as an important event. I was accorded a great welcome and enormous hospitality by members of His Majesty's government.

PARA.TAB: While in Jordan I had the good fortune to be invited to participate in the University of Sydney's archaeological mission to Pella, about which I want to say a few words. Pella is a large site in the northern Jordan located some three kilometres east of the Jordan River, opposite Bet She'an in Israel. It is perhaps one of the most important sites in Jordan. In fact, it has been recognised as one of the most important sites in the entire Levantine region. Indeed, Sydney University is very privileged to have a long association with the work in that place.

The site contains habitation remains from the chalcolithic period, roughly 4500 BC, to modern Islamic remains. The nearby region is rewriting the prehistory of humankind, with Aechulien stone tools dating to circa 250,000 BC located in the rock strata. These stone tools were located by the Sydney University team at its last season and in previous years, and I had the privilege of personally examining those implements.

Sydney University has been working at the site for nearly 15 years examining not only the main tell but the neighbouring region. Under the auspices of Professor Basil Hennessy, successive teams have progressively uncovered a broad range of remains spanning all the periods that I have outlined. Following a brief hiatus caused by the Gulf war, the team of which I was a member returned once again to excavate the main tell under the auspices of Dr Stephen Bourke.

Work concentrated in the main area where several existing trenches were reopened to gain a further understanding of the underlying strata. By the season's end important early Bronze Age housing had been unearthed, along with the remains of an early Bronze Age fortress dating to roughly 3000 BC. Further work was conducted on the so-called late Bronze Age governor's residence dating to 1300 BC, or the late eighteenth, early nineteenth dynasty in Egypt, at the time of Rameses the Great. A beautiful clay astarte figurine—complete—was one of the most important finds of this period that was found at the recent excavations.

I spent a total of three weeks in the field, excavating a small two by two metre sondage that had been uncovered in an area in which a large amount of remains from the early Iron Age period had already been uncovered. My goal was to dig as quickly as I could to excavate down to the bedrock at the base of the habitation remains. After three weeks I had excavated a three metre deep trench and had in fact achieved my research goal of reaching the bedrock and in doing so had uncovered quite substantial layers of human habitation floor remains and a dump fill which had been placed upon those floors by people in ancient times.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is not a learned society; it is the Senate!

—Yes, I am fully aware of that. As I said earlier, the work had achieved all its research goals. Bedrock had been reached in two other places. It is now the team's hope to be able to move on to more fruitful areas.

PARA.TAB: The project, as I outlined, is important for Jordanian archaeology, and to that extent we recognise the support of the Jordanian antiquities authority, in particular the support of Doctor Safwan Tell, the director of the department. The work is funded by a grant from the ARC and by a special grant from the Australian National Gallery. These two organisations recognise the international importance of the project, both in scholarly and foreign policy terms. I would like to dwell on that latter point for a moment.

Australia and Australians are well regarded in Jordan as well as in the rest of the Middle East. We have significant trade links. In fact, in 1990, 4.8 per cent of our total exports went to countries in that region. Half of those exports were wheat but many more were other primary products. Manufactured goods and minerals processing products are becoming an increasing part of Australian exports to that region. In addition, we have significant and expanding markets for barley and other processed exports. To this extent it is my hope and the hope of the Democrats that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and Australian businesses will seek to expand the opportunities that exist for Australian primary products in the Middle East.

Jordan, by comparison, is not a large trading partner for Australia as it ranks as our sixty-ninth largest export market and is outside the top 10 of our largest Middle Eastern trading partners. It is only a small country. However, I do believe that there are significant opportunities there which should be explored by Australian business.

I had the opportunity of discussing these issues with Jordanian Government leaders, which was very valuable for me in gaining a greater understanding of the relationship between our country and the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan. I will say more on that score in a speech later in the year.

I would like to express my thanks for the hospitality extended to me by His Majesty King Hussein and Her Majesty Queen Noor el Hussein and for the warm welcome I was accorded by members of His Majesty's Government. I am particularly grateful to the Prime Minister, His Excellency Mr Sharif Zeid bin Shaker, for receiving me and my husband, Mr Armon Hicks.

In conclusion, I would like to thank the Jordanian Ambassador to Australia, Mr Saad Bataineh, and I would also like to thank the Australian Ambassador to Jordan, Mr Bob Bowker, and his wife, Jenny, for their hospitality and their organisation of my official engagements while in Jordan. They are a credit to Australia, they are very highly regarded by the Jordanian Government and in fact by Middle Eastern leaders, and they both exhibit and show a deep understanding of Middle Eastern affairs. I think it is a great credit to Australia that we can send people to these countries who are so highly regarded and who are a real credit to the people of Australia.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Trade Practices Commission: `Prosper from Petrol' Campaign

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a matter of concern regarding the conduct of one of the Government's key business regulatory agencies. For some 18 months the Trade Practices Commission has pursued, at massive cost to both itself and thus the Commonwealth and the Australian taxpayer, and at a similar massive cost to a respected trade association, the Motor Trades Association of Australia (MTAA), a course of action which has led to charges being laid against the Service Station Association of New South Wales, its honorary president and its executive director. The Service Station Association of New South Wales is a member of the MTAA. I do not want to canvass the substance of the issues involved; they will be decided in a case commencing in the Federal Court on 15 June. Considering the limited amount of time available, I seek leave to have my copious notes incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The notes read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: As background, however, the alleged breaches of the Trade Practices Act relate to a campaign endorsed by the Board of Directors of the Motor Trades Association of Australia known as `Prosper from Petrol'. The aim of this education campaign, elements of which were also adopted by a number of other member bodies of MTAA was to educate service station operators in how to avoid selling petrol at a loss and thus to earn a decent return of their labour and capital investment. At the time it was launched, many thousands of service station operators were in serious financial difficulty and were running their businesses at a loss, as indeed they still are.

Details of this campaign were put before the TPC by the MTAA who, in fact, asked the TPC for its advice. At no time did the TPC advise that any part of the campaign was unacceptable. I am seriously concerned at the TPC's conduct in assembling its case and I believe that the Attorney-General should be making himself aware of the circumstances surrounding:

PARA.TAB: the taking of evidence
the summoning of witnesses
the way that witnesses were treated

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission has investigated similar allegations against individuals in the past but unlike its previous investigations, in this instance the Commission wheeled out the intimidatory and draconian powers available to it under Section 155 of the Trade Practices Act. Service station operators were required to present themselves for an examination by counsel for, and officials of, the TPC in circumstances where, on occasion, this interrogation continued over several days. Those who had to appear were discouraged from having legal representation and initially were denied access to transcripts of their interviews.
Further, in submitting themselves for questioning they were required under oath to answer questions even if those answers might incriminate them.
This is totally at odds with the basic natural justice and legal principles on which Australian society is based.
It appears that the TPC have brought out the cannons and opened fire without first identifying the enemy.

I am also concerned that the TPC in pursuing its case decided to begin legal action against a trade association and its members without first raising its concerns with that association. This is despite a cordial and accessible relationship between the TPC and the MTAA, whose executive director has served as a member of the TPC's national consultative committee since 1989.

The MTAA has cooperated with government bodies including the TPC and the Prices Surveillance Authority to address structural problems confronting the petroleum industry. Immediately prior to the commencement of the TPC's investigations MTAA had committed substantial resources to assist the TPC in its review of the industry.
The cooperation between MTAA and the TPC led to the introduction of a voluntary code of practice known as `oilcode' to resolve disputes between refiners and petrol resellers.
I am puzzled and alarmed therefore by the TPC's behaviour. Why did the TPC not raise its concerns with MTAA about the matters it is pursuing in the Federal court?
Why did the TPC begin a covert investigation whilst informing that its `Prosper from Petrol' campaign was acceptable?
Why did the TPC advise MTAA's members that they could lawfully issue recommended prices under the Trade Practices Act if the TPC had any concerns about the campaign?

The Trade Practices Act specifically sets out that the TPC has the power and, it might be argued, a duty to enter a process of discussion and negotiation. Such a conciliatory approach may have alerted the Association to the TPC's concerns and allowed for amicable resolution.
Instead it embarked on a course of:

PARA.TAB: oppressive and excessive interrogation of witnesses
claims and charges of a quasi-criminal nature directed at officials and employees of the Association

initiating a process whereby the Commission has perhaps already spent up to half a million dollars of public money on legal costs and forced the MTAA into expenditure matching that amount if it wishes to defend the case

producing a situation whereby an individual honorary officer of the Service Station Association of NSWand the Association's executive director are now liable for fines of up to $50,000 per charge for numerous alleged breaches of the Act.

SPEECH.PARA: I am concerned that the TPC showed no inclination to discuss or even indicate its concerns. Instead it has chosen in a cavalier fashion to manipulate a section of the Trade Practices Act to assault a voluntary body.

We are left wondering where this must leave the elected officials who perform sterling voluntary service in the hundreds of trade and industry associations scattered throughout Australia. If at some future time they are to be singled out for such action by the TPC for some perceived fault then very quickly those associations will die. Who would wish to take the risk of being an office-holder in the face of the risks which have come to light through this unprecedented action?
The Senate and the Parliament must take this matter very seriously. I intend to take the matter further by asking the Attorney-General his view as to

PARA.TAB: whether the TPC has acted properly,
whether the case is one in which it should have pursued such a zealous, some would say over-zealous, action and used extremely intimidatory powers to do so
whether this is an efficient use of the TPC's limited resources

whether such legal action should be taken against officials of an association while at the same time, after interrogating a large number of service station operators, the TPC has apparently not found any grounds to charge, and thus has laid no charges against, any individual operator.

SPEECH.PARA: The Attorney-General has the power to intervene in such cases and I believe he must give serious consideration to so doing. I shall be ensuring that he considers the matter. In the meantime, tens of thousands of people working in the motor trades in Australia, all of whom are aware of this case and its possible ramifications for the future activity of their association, must ask senators and members where they stand on this matter that embodies much of crucial importance to small business in Australia today.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Aboriginal Deaths in Custody--Tobacco Advertising and Sponsorship

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the Senate should be grateful to Senator Knowles for making it aware of the statements that Senator Chamarette has made because I find those statements that she has been reported to have made quite offensive. Usually, when people become members of the Senate, they wait for a few weeks until they understand the system before they become critical. But the new senator appears to have put her foot right in her proverbial mouth. She may come into this Senate believing that she is the only one concerned about Aboriginal welfare, but she is going to find that this Senate gives bipartisan support for the welfare of our indigenous community. So if she comes in here and accuses the Government and the Opposition of not being interested or not being prepared to debate the very important issue of Aboriginal deaths in custody, she is being absolutely ignorant and showing no respect for her colleagues on all sides of the Parliament.

PARA.TAB: That is not the prime reason that I rose today. I am concerned about the Government's decision to ban tobacco advertising. I am concerned for a number of reasons. What does one ban next? If one bans a legal product—it is legal to sell it, it is legal to produce it, it is legal to use it—then there are a lot of other ramifications. What is next—alcohol, guns, or anything about which people may hold a different view? I think it is a very dangerous precedent to set. It is not, in my opinion, in the best interests of the overall community.

I understand the arguments for the banning; I understand them only too well. I have chosen not to smoke, and my family has done likewise. But to construe that we should ban tobacco advertising because of health reasons is something that does not sit very well with me. If the Senate wished to debate whether tobacco should be banned because it is a health risk, I think that would be a more direct way to go. If we were to ban tobacco as a product, then the Senate could argue the merits of that. But what we are trying to do is to have it both ways—to have a product that is legal and one which we are trying to choke by underhand methods.

I am concerned also for the 600 tobacco growers who make their living from the tobacco industry. The region of Queensland that relies totally on the tobacco growing industry is an area around Mareeba, and 350-odd tobacco growers came to Canberra only a couple of weeks ago to see the Government, and were here this week to see the Opposition.

I want to make this point very strongly: there are moves to get rid of that tobacco industry by taking the mix of 57 per cent from the industry and by a number of other ways that are going to weaken the industry, including the removal of advertising. I say to the Senate that if these tobacco growers lose their industry and the industry does close down in north Queensland, where about 60 per cent of the tobacco is grown, that is not going to solve the health problem in Australia, because that product that is grown in Australia will be replaced by imports.

It may be argued that, because of subsidies and a number of other market distortions, tobacco will come into Australia at a much cheaper rate, which would encourage more people to smoke. But I am concerned, as I have said before, that it is the thin edge of the wedge, as I think one other senator mentioned. Neither the Government's decision nor the Opposition's response has gone to the party room. When it does, I will be arguing very strongly to vote against any reduction or any removal of tobacco advertising in Australia. It is up to everyone to make a decision on whether they want to smoke cigarettes or not. People should have the liberty to make the choice. To take people's choice away from them and to interfere with the right of companies to advertise a legal product is not in the best interests of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 5 December 1991:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the World Declaration on the Survival, Protection and Development of Children, signed by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on 13 May 1991, and the letter from the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development (Dr Blewett) of 24 June 1991 regarding Australia's assistance to developing countries to achieve the objectives of the Declaration, and his statement that expenditure for this purpose would be addressed in the context of the 1991-92 Budget, did the 1991-92 Budget contain a specific allocation for the implementation of Australia's commitments under the World Declaration on the Survival, Protection and Development of Children; if so, what is the relevant budget item and the amount allocated under that item; if not, when and how does the Government intend to meet its obligation under the Declaration.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: While no line item was identified in the 1991-92 Budget in respect of Australia's obligations under the World Declaration on the Survival, Protection and Development of Children, the Government provided additional funding under a number of existing programs including additional funding of $400,000 for UNICEF. Funding of further proposals relating to our obligations under the Declaration will be considered in the 1992-93 Budget following completion of the National Plan of Action which will set out Australia's response to the Declaration.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer upon notice, on 27 February 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Treasurer's press release of 21 February 1992 `Opposition superannuation plans—another consumption tax package casualty—another wheel falls off':
(1) What is the basis of the claim that raising the fund earnings tax from 15 per cent to 25 per cent would reduce national savings.

(2) What empirical studies have been performed demonstrating that the Coalition's superannuation policies will reduce either the national savings ratio or national savings, who performed them and by how much did these studies show that either the national savings ratio or national savings will fall as a result of the Coalition's superannuation policies.
(3) What definition of national savings has been used.

(4) What evidence is there that the Government's regime of superannuation tax concessions and its proposed superannuation guarantee levy (SGL) will lead to a discernible increase in national savings and the national savings ratio.
(5) What forecast percentage point changes in the national savings ratio does the Treasurer expect due to the proposed SGL (a) 12 months; (b) two years; and (c) five years after its introduction.
(6) What are the anticipated consequences for employment and employment growth of the introduction of the SGL.

(7) What will be the impact of the SGL on Government savings in its first full year of operation, and what are all the assumptions required to generate such a finding, including the increase in Government income support outlays for those Australians who lose their jobs as a result of the introduction of the SGL.

(8) Does the Treasurer agree with the view put forward by Senator Walsh in his article in the Australian Financial Review of 27 August 1991 entitled `Australia will pay for super cargo cult' that the proposed SGL is a `de facto payroll tax' and that the move to payroll-tax-funding of superannuation will lengthen the unemployment spells already experienced by marginal members of the workforce; if not, why not.

(9) Does the Treasurer also agree with Senator Walsh, who, in the same article, argues that there will be savings `switching' as a result of the SGL, in that individuals will reduce discretionary savings to compensate for enforced saving through the SGL, if not, why not; if so, for each dollar invested in superannuation as a result of the SGL, what is the estimated reduction in other forms of private savings to offset, either in part or in full, enforced SGL savings; if there is no such an estimate, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question on notice:

PARA.TAB: (1) The press release to which Senator Alston's question refers indicated that the complexities of the Opposition's superannuation package combined with the proposed increase in taxation of fund earnings from 15 to 25 per cent would increase the tax on many people's superannuation and that this would reduce national savings. An increase in the earnings tax will directly reduce the after-tax earnings of superannuation funds and is likely to reduce the incentive, particularly for those people on a marginal tax rate of 20 per cent, for accumulating superannuation savings.
(2) and (3) No empirical studies have been performed by the Treasury.

(4) The Government's policies will ensure that virtually all employees will be making superannuation savings equivalent to at least 9 per cent of earnings by the year 2000. This can be expected to increase national savings over time because:

ANSWER.PARA: higher superannuation savings will not be fully offset by reductions in other savings because many employees do not have equivalent levels of non-superannuation savings and superannuation savings are not a perfect substitute for other savings; and
as increases in superannuation cover are to be taken into account in wage negotiations, employers net savings positions should not change significantly.

PARA.TAB: (5) No forecasts of this type are available.

(6) The scope for wages growth from other sources will necessarily be lower than otherwise so as to ensure that enhanced superannuation does not impact adversely on cost structures, inflation and employment. If wages growth were to become inconsistent with achieving inflation rates comparable with those of our major trading partners, the Government will reconsider the scheduled timing of increases in the prescribed minimum standard of superannuation.

(7) The SGL is not expected to impact on Government revenues in its first year of operation, because superannuation taxation revenue is collected with a lag of one year. The SGL will reduce revenues in later years due to the lower average tax rate applying to remuneration paid as superannuation contributions. However, the effect of the SGL on Government savings cannot be isolated from the broader setting of fiscal policy.

(8) The SGL is a retirement incomes policy initiative designed to encourage employers to comply with their obligation to provide superannuation support to their employees. It cannot be characterised as a payroll tax because it applies only where an employer has not provided adequate superannuation cover in respect of his or her employees and because an equivalent amount to the revenue raised, less administrative expenses, is redistributed in the form of superannuation contributions to the affected employees.

(9) Some substitution of superannuation for non-superannuation savings can reasonably be expected. However, as indicated in (4) above there is unlikely to be complete substitution. No estimate of the likely magnitude of this effect is available.

(10) If such initiatives are planned, will payment be withdrawn in cases where the pharmacist provides PBS drugs to a person whose fringe benefits card indicates entitlement but who has foregone entitlement subsequent to the issuing of the card.
(11) To what extent does the Federal Government intend to consult with pharmacists and pharmacy representatives prior to the introduction of any such initiatives.
(12) If such initiatives are introduced, what efforts will the Federal Government also undertake to penalise individuals who knowingly try to cheat the Pharmaceutical Benefits Program.

(13) What are the estimated annual financial savings that the Federal Government will derive from withdrawal of payments to pharmacists under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Program in cases where concessionary rate drugs are provided to non-entitled persons.
(14) Will any such initiatives to withdraw payments to pharmacists also be applied to medical practitioners who dispense drugs under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Program.

(15) Will pharmacists to whom payment has been withdrawn in relation to cases where concessionary rate drugs have been dispensed to non-entitled persons be provided with a list of the offending cases.
(16) Will pharmacists be able to seek the difference from non-entitled beneficiaries at a later date if they find out that they have not charged them at the required rate.

(17) What appeal mechanisms will be available to pharmacists who dispute non-payment by the Federal Government in relation to cases where non-entitled persons have been provided with drugs at the concessionary rate.
(18) What other penalties will the Federal Government be able to enforce on pharmacists who dispense drugs to non-entitled persons at the concessionary rate.
(19) Will any initiatives to withdraw payment to pharmacists also extend to non-Medicare Card holders who claim drugs at the general rate under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Program.

(20) What legislative or regulatory amendments, if any, will be required before the Government can implement any proposal to restrict payment to pharmacists who dispense drugs to non-entitled persons at the concessionary rate.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Commonwealth Government, through the Health Insurance Commission, has begun a program of checking the entitlements of persons who claim they have an entitlement to free or concessional pharmaceutical benefits.

ANSWER.PARA: the construction of the person's entitlement number by the Health Insurance Commission, to ensure that it has been correctly entered by the pharmacist and to assist in determining the validity of the patient entitlement; and
the patient's entitlement status at the time of dispensing by the pharmacist.

PARA.TAB: (2) From 9 March 1992, the Health Insurance Commission commenced a program of advising pharmacists that they had claimed for prescriptions for which:

ANSWER.PARA: they had provided an invalid entitlement number; or
the recorded entitlement number was no longer current.

PARA.TAB: (3) Where a pharmacist's claim contains prescriptions for which an invalid entitlement number has been recorded or where no entitlement has been found, the Commission will adhere to the following procedures from 1 July 1992:

ANSWER.PARA: Where the prescription data supplied to the Health Insurance Commission by a pharmacist contains an invalid entitlement number:

PARA.TAB: in the first instance of each invalid entitlement number occurring in a claim sent to the Commission, the pharmacist will be advised on the Statement of Account (routinely returned by the Health Insurance Commission after each claim); and
subsequent prescriptions claimed by a pharmacist, which still contain the invalid entitlement number, will be rejected and returned to the pharmacist;

ANSWER.PARA: where there is a claim sent to the Commission by a pharmacist for a benefit dated after the expiry date shown on the entitlement card:

PARA.TAB: the prescription will be rejected by the Commission and returned to the pharmacist;

ANSWER.PARA: where there is a claim sent to the Commission by a pharmacist, for a benefit dated before the expiry date on the entitlement card, but after eligibility has in fact been withdrawn by the Departments of Social Security or Veterans' Affairs:

PARA.TAB: in the first instance of each invalid entitlement number, the pharmacist will be advised of the error(s) by the Commission on the return Statement of Account; and
subsequent prescriptions claimed by a pharmacist after notification, which still contain the invalid entitlement number, will be rejected and returned to the pharmacist.

(4) The non-interactive eligibility checking system is currently being developed and existing cards will be reviewed in consultation with The Department of Social Security and The Department of Veterans' Affairs as necessary throughout this process.
(5) to (8) These questions are matters for my colleague the Minister for Social Security.
(9) The checking procedures, outlined above, apply whether drugs are required urgently or not.

Where the Health Insurance Commission has no record of a patient having an entitlement to a free or concessional benefit, or the pharmacist has been warned previously that no entitlement exists, the prescription will be rejected and returned to the pharmacist. If subsequent proof is supplied by the patient of entitlement, a refund is available to the patient under section 87A of the National Health Act 1953.

(10) Where a person's entitlement to a concessional benefit has been withdrawn prior to the expiry date shown on the card, the Health Insurance Commission will pay the prescription and advise the pharmacist concerned. Prescriptions containing the expired entitlement number, supplied after notification, will be rejected by the Commission and returned to the pharmacist.

(11) The Commonwealth Government, through the Health Insurance Commission, has been consulting with the Pharmacy Guild of Australia for some time over the general issues of eligibility for pharmaceutical benefits.

Following the joint report by the Auditor-General and the Department of Finance on the Government's proposals for an interactive processing system, the Health Insurance Commission has discussed and is continuing to discuss its non-interactive proposals for the checking of patients' eligibility for concessional benefits with the Pharmacy Guild.

(12) Individuals caught attempting to obtain a pharmaceutical benefit(s) to which they are not entitled will be dealt with under paragraph 103 (5)(b) of the National Health Act 1953. The maximum penalty for contravention is $5000 or two years imprisonment or both.

(13) The Health Insurance Commission has indicated, based on the latest Audit analysis, that the alternative measures outlined above, should enable them to prevent 70% of the errors and invalid claims, that the interactive system would have been able to detect. Therefore, it is estimated that between $8.4m and $12.6m would be able to be saved if the alternative measures are successful.
(14) Any initiatives to withdraw payments, which apply to pharmacists, would also apply to approved medical practitioners and approved hospitals.

(15) Where a number is incorrect or there is no current entitlement, the error(s) will be noted by the Commission on the return Statement of Account so that the pharmacist can take corrective action for future claims.

(16) Pharmacists would be entitled to seek the difference between the required rate and the rate charged from non-entitled beneficiaries from the individual(s) at a later date under section 87 and section 92A of the National Health Act 1953.
(17) A pharmacist, who has acted in good faith and who believes he has been treated unfairly, may approach the Health Insurance Commission to have the case reconsidered.

Subsection 105AB(12) of the National Health Act 1953 provides for an Administrative Appeals Tribunal application for review of a decision not to pay a claim under subsection 99AAA(6). The Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 is also available to pharmacists who wish to dispute non-payment by the Commonwealth Government in the cases indicated.

(18) If the supply by the pharmacist at the incorrect rate was deliberate, the offence provisions of section 103 of the National Health Act 1953 would come into play, especially 103(5)(h), 103(5)(g), and 103(4A). A range of penalties apply to those who contravene this section of the Act. For those who contravene subsections 103(5)(h), 103(5)(g), and 103(4A) the maximum penalty is $5000 or two years imprisonment or both.
(19) Restriction of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme to Medicare card holders ("eligible persons") has been removed following the decision not to proceed with interactive eligibility checking.
(20) No further legislation is necessary or planned at this point to implement any proposal to restrict payment to pharmacists who dispense drugs to non-entitled persons at the concessional rate.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 5 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What analysis has the Department undertaken of proposed sites for the relocation of the School of Artillery from North Head, Sydney.
(2) What criteria has the Department set for the evaluation of possible sites.

(3) What consideration has the Department given to locating the school in central Queensland, particularly the Rockhampton area, given the close proximity to the Shoalwater Bay Training Area, existing adequate infrastructure, relevant climate conditions, civilian rationing contracting capability and community support for the project.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Detailed and comprehensive studies were conducted into the issue of the future location of the School of Artillery during 1987 and 1988. These studies were re-examined in the Force Structure Review process conducted in 1991 and are subject to on-going Departmental consideration.
(2) The criteria used to evaluate possible sites reflect strategic, operational, personnel, administrative support, infrastructure and cost considerations.
(3) Rockhampton was one of the site options considered for a future site for the School of Artillery.
